Enormous triplane bomber N-531: "Six Liberty-engined triplanes, retroactively called Ca.42, were briefly operated from Taranto-Pizzone by the British Royal Naval Air Service with serials N526-N531. The Caproni Flight, as the new unit was called, was led by Squadron Commander R. Whitehead. The increased power cut climbing times in half while adding 500 kg of payload and raising the top speed by 15 km per hour." flyingmachines.ru/Images7/Caproni/76-1.jpg wpalette.com/en/pictures/33412 Flickr user Stig Jarlevik captioned this photo as follows: "Stig Jarlevik 4y This is RNAS final Ca.4 on loan. N531, and used by Northern Squadron, 6th Wing at Otranto. Possibly even shot when it was delivered during the week ending on 26.1.1918. Said to have been handed back to the Italians on 30.3.1918, but also said to have been on loan and used by RAF's 227 Sq at Pizzone until December 1918. Most probably, since RAF was formed on April 1st 1918, it was a papertransaction only. Cheers Stig" see

From a WWI forum: "The hospital at Auteuil wasn’t a 'field' hospital (as stated in the ADB for Dr Sexton) – it was a small hospital (initially of 21 beds) established in a private villa set in large grounds in Paris, close to the Bois de Boulogne. Although privately & voluntarily run by a small group of Australian women, it operated in connection with the military hospital at Val de Grace under the auspices of the French Military Authorities, and catered to French wounded. Established in July 1915, it was later either closed, or taken over by the French authorities in January 1916. The founders were Mrs Smith (wife of Colonel William Smith, AAMC – of Sth Yarra), together with her 2 daughters Alison & Lorna (who were talented cooks); Mrs Blackwood (wife of Robert O. Blackwood); & of course Dr Helen Sexton. The 2 trained nursing staff working with them were Florence Lilian Inglis (later AVH & QAIMNSR) & Dora Wilson (both having trained at Prince Alfred Hosp, Sydney). [Audrey & Eileen Chomley may have also worked there] From what I've read, Dr Sexton was the only female doctor involved in the hospital, although there were a few male consulting physicians. The address of the hospital was: Hospital Australien de Paris (Complimentaire da Val de Grace, V.G., 81), 46 Rue du Docteur Blanche, Auteuil, Paris. After leaving the Hospital Australien in Jan 1916, Dr Sexton & Mrs Blackwood took up positions at the Buffon Military Hospital – a large French military hospital, also in Paris." More info, with citations, at: 1914-1918.invisionzone.com/forums/index.php?/topic/198004...
A photo of the entire hospital compound, with the Eiffel Tower in the background: history.amedd.army.mil/booksdocs/wwi/fieldoperations/ch10...
Art Siegel:  Thanks for the background information on the Auteuil hospital.  We will include more description for it next time we update these records.
The hospital still exists. See www.american-hospital.org/en/american-hospital-of-paris/a...

"The Evening News, Harrisburg, Penna., Thursday, July 11, 1918 Another Harrisburger Is Killed in War; LOCAL SOLDIER WHO DIED IN BATTLE WAS WITH 4TH REGULARS Penn Street Lad Who Died Fighting the Huns CORPORAL GORNER [photo] Corporal William O. Gorner, 1916 Penn street, is the latest Harrisburg boy to die in France fighting for world democracy. A telegram from the War Department, received by his wife, Mrs. Lorena Gorner, brought to Harrisburg the news that he had made the supreme sacrifice and the information also was contained in the Government's official casualty list published this morning. The casualty list stated merely that he had been "killed in action" in France. Gorner, who volunteered and enlisted at the Harrisburg Army Recruiting Station, 325 Market street, just one year ago this month, was placed in the Fourth Infantry. That is one of the old regiments of the Regular Army and was in camp at Gettysburg at that time. Because of its having been one of the units established before the war, the Fourth had but few vacancies to fill and Gorner was assigned to one of these. While it was known at the local recruiting station that the Fourth had arrived in England a number of weeks ago the news of Corporal Gorner's death brought the first intimation received here that the Fourth had subsequently not only reached French soil but evidently had seen action on the firing line. It was stated at the recruiting station, however, that the Fourth, being one of the old regiments of regulars, was well trained and equipped to be put right into the fighting. Mrs. Gorner resides at the Penn street address with Mrs. J. H. Keezy. She and her husband lived there before his enlistment. The notice from Washington came as a terrific shock to the widow, particularly as Corporal Gorner has been abroad less than two months. After being assigned to Company A, 4th Infantry, stationed at Gettysburg, Gorner and his unit were transferred to Camp Greene, Charlotte, North Carolina. About May 1 he sailed with his division to England from Newport News. Gorner who was 32 years old, was a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gorner, of Marietta. There he lived until his marriage, when he and his wife moved to 1916 Penn street, this city, where they boarded with Mrs. Keezy. Previous to his enlistment, the Corporal was employed as a brakeman on the Philadelphia Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The young soldier who has met death was a brother of Frank Gorner, to whom was awarded a medal for bravery last Decoration Day on account of his having saved several persons from drowning in the Susquehanna River. Corporal Gorner is survived by his wife, parents and one brother. Widow Prostrated by News of Gorner's Death When the news of the death of Corporal W. O. Gorner, who was killed while fighting Huns in France, reached Mrs. Gorner late last evening she was prostrated and up until a late hour today was still confined to her bed. Her condition however, is not considered alarming. Although Mrs. Gorner was not able to be seen by a reporter, her sister said that as soon as the first shock of the news passed, the widow declared she was proud that her husband had died in the service of his Country. " files.usgwarchives.net/pa/dauphin/newspapers/en-1918-7-11...
More at www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Gorner...;

There are a lot of Tokugawas , but I think it is this one: "Prince Tokugawa Iesato (徳川 家達?, August 24, 1863 – June 5, 1940) was the first head of the Tokugawa clan after the overthrow of the Tokugawa bakufu, and a figure in Japanese politics during the Meiji, Taishō and early Shōwa period Japan." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tokugawa_Iesato Other pictures at commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Tokugawa_Iesato
Art Siegel: Thanks.  We will include his more complete identification next time we update.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog]  
Hello Art Siegel,
I've recently written an illustrated biography titled THE ART OF PEACE on Prince Tokugawa Iesato. The biography is available as an eBook on AMAZON. The individual in the photo labeled Prince Tokugawa with the number 4660-12 is actually Iesato's only son, Iemasa Tokugawa (also spelled Iyemasa Tokugawa). Both father and son worked together to maintain goodwill between the East and the West, and achieved amazing accomplishments. The second photo linked to hunting might well also be Iyemasa Tokugawa. 
Regards,
Stan S. Katz

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/anne_loc] 
Hello Anna,
I've recently written an illustrated biography titled THE ART OF PEACE on Prince Tokugawa Iesato. The biography is available as an eBook on AMAZON. The individual in the photo labeled Prince Tokugawa with the number 4660-12 is actually Iesato's only son, Iemasa Tokugawa (also spelled Iyemasa Tokugawa). William J. Reilly, U.S. Navy sailor, stationed on the battleship U.S.S. Michigan, was a popular singer. pages.stolaf.edu/americanmusic/tag/william-j-reilly/
The photos were taken on the USS Recruit en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Recruit_(1917)

According to this September, 1917 item from The New York Clipper, he was doing recruiting and (presumably patriotic) vaudeville: "SAILOR REILLY GETS 16 WEEKS William J. Reilly, who appeared in vaudeville recently, putting over a piano-logue and aiding in the recruiting for the Navy, will receive four months' leave from the battleship Michigan on December 28. He will use the time in playing sixteen weeks of vaudeville, opening January 7 at Keith's Theatre, Washington." fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?uri=http%... In August, 1918, he was identified as a sergeant and was performing at a childrens war savings rally in Madison Square Garden with the U.S.S. Recruit band: "Sergeant William J. Reilly. who is now on recruiting duty, claimed the undivided attention of the large audience of youngsters when he sang "Keep Your Head Down, Frltzie Boy." and "Over There." fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?uri=http%...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Burr "Henry Burr (January 15, 1882 – April 6, 1941) was a Canadian singer of popular songs in the early 20th century, an early radio performer and producer. He was born Harry Haley McClaskey and used Henry Burr as one of his many pseudonyms, in addition to Irving Gillette, Henry Gillette, Alfred Alexander, Robert Rice, Carl Ely, Harry Barr, Frank Knapp, Al King, and Shamus McClaskey. He was one of the first singers to make popular acoustic recordings and one of the most prolific recording artists of all time, with more than 12,000 recordings by his own estimate. A tenor, he performed as a soloist and also in duets, trios and quartets. His most famous collaboration was the Peerless Quartet."

Presumably en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Sharkey "Thomas 'Sailor Tom' Sharkey (November 26, 1873 – April 17, 1953) was a boxer who fought two fights with heavyweight champion James J. Jeffries. Sharkey's recorded ring career spanned from 1893 to 1904. "

The event depicted here is likely Sharkey's effort, in the summer of 1918 (at the age of 44), to be sent to France by the YMCA as an athletic instructor. The YMCA didn't approve him. The YMCA magazine "Association Men" for September, 1918, ran this account: "The Statement Gained Wide Publicity in the press that Tom Sharkey had been accepted for overseas service. It was a mistake. Mr Sharkey had a boy abroad in the army and volunteered with all good intentions feeling that his athletic ability might be used in the service. It was impossible however as his life long connections with the ring, the saloon, and the dive and the police courts could not justify the committee accepting him. A wide publicity had been given however to his application and an over eager press agent had borrowed an Association suit and cap and had him photographed and statements sent abroad that he was going under the Association auspices." and elsewhere: "Tom Sharkey was not accepted for overseas service. This impossible thing did not happen as appeared in a New York paper: "Impossible things Are transpiring today Tom Sharkey has gone with the YMCA." Here is a revised version written by a secretary's wife" Some things have not Happened today Tom Sharkey never got into the YMCA." books.google.com/books?id=XWQzAQAAMAAJ&printsec=front... George Bellows' famous painting "A Stag at Sharkey's" depicts an illegal fight held in the basement of Sharkey's bar at Broadway and 65th. Another account: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B05E4D6173EE4...

More info from a Nassau (NY) Post article, July 5, 1918: The goal of the Victory Special tour was "to teach the women of Long Island how best to help their country by conforming with the newest food regulations. The demonstrations will include ways of preparing other conservation foods and the most approved methods of canning and preserving vegetables and fruits. More than one hundred persons can be accommodated comfortably in the demonstration car. The schedule of this traveling war emergency school for housewives, is as follows: Flushing, July 8; Jamaica, July 9; Freeport, July 10; Patchogue, July 11; Bridgehampton, July 12; Greenport, July 13; Riverhead, July 15; Farmingdale, July 16; Port Jefferson, July 17; Huntington, July 18; Oyster Bay, July 19; Mineola, July 20" nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn95071434/1918-07-05/ed-1...

The Handley Page Type O was an early biplane bomber used by Britain during the First World War. At the time, it was the largest aircraft that had been built in the UK and one of the largest in the world. It was built in two major versions, the Handley Page O/100 (H.P.11) and Handley Page O/400 (H.P.12). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handley_Page_Type_O

This appears to be the Handley Page V/1500 bomber. It is distinguished from the Handley Page Type O (and variants) by its equal span wings and four Rolls-Royce Eagle V-12 engines. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handley_Page_V/1500

The Bismarck tribune., July 19, 1918, Image 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042243/1918-07-19/ed-... shows this picture, with caption, "A front view of the giant super-biplane, the Handley-Page, which will fly across the Atlantic when the allies get ready to send a fleet of planes to bombard Berlin. Ten thousand duplicates of this air monster, built in the United States, could cross the ocean in 60 days, bombard dozens of German cities and end the war, says W. H. Workman, American representative of Handley-Page, Ltd., of England. Note the size of the plane in comparison with the 14 men who are standing around its wheels." Copyright there was claimed by Underwood & Underwood. NYT of June 30, 1918 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A02E2D8103BEE3AB... has more about the project proposal.
See defenceoftherealm.wordpress.com/2015/08/06/handley-page-h... for more about the Handley Page HP.15 V/1500 plane and its context.

Since the first V/1500 to come to the States came in 1919 and this negative has 7/1/18 as a scribbled date, I assume the pictures were taken in Britain, probably at Cricklewood, and distributed by W. H. Workman as he tried to persuade the U.S. to build some of them.

All three photos of the plane have a triangular mark at bottom right, which may identify the original source, but I have been unable to interpret it.

The evening world., July 06, 1918, Final Edition, Page 6, col. 6 reported that "a giant bombing airplane - said to be the largest built in this country so far - was launched this afternoon at Elizabeth, N. J. ... The machine, built at the plant of the Standard Aircraft Corporation, is constructed on plans furnished by Handley-Page, Ltd., the British concern which has furnished thousands of machines to the Allies." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1918-07-06/ed-... Photos of this event are in lcweb2.loc.gov/service/sgp/sgpnyt/1918/191807/19180714/00... But the airplane shown there is apparently a Handley Page Type O, not a V/1500 as depicted here.

This is a photo of the first prototype of the Handley Page V/1500 B9463 during rigging checks at Clutterhouse Farm at Cricklewood, late April 1918.
The aircraft had been sent as components from Harland & Wolff, Belfast, Northern ireland and was finally assembled by Handley Page on 21 April 1918. 
First flight was not achieved until 22 May 1918.
It crashed on its 13th flight 2 June 1918 and was completely destroyed

The taller building on the right is the Bank of the Metropolis building (1903).  This building still stands and, appropriately for a building which was once adjacent to a battleship, is now home to the Blue Water Grill. Giuseppe De Luca (25 December 1876 – 26 August 1950), was an Italian baritone who achieved his greatest triumphs at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City. He notably created roles in the world premieres of two operas by Giacomo Puccini: Sharpless in Madama Butterfly (at La Scala, Milan, 1904) and the title role in Gianni Schicchi (Metropolitan Opera, 1918). en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giuseppe_De_Luca

"Soliders of the Great War (1920)," a multi-volume work that listed all of the US soldiers killed in WWI, has him listed under "Killed In Action" as opposed to "Died of Wounds" or "Died of Disease". The casualty report published on April 1, 1918 has him listed as "Slightly Wounded". Another report from June 11, 1918 lists him as "Killed in Action".
According to www.genealogybuff.com/misc/ww1/il-ww1-ago-casualties186.htm -- casualties reported on June 14, 1918, Mirko Ivosevich, Midland, Pa. was killed in action.

From "First Over There: The Attack on Cantigny, America's First Battle of World War I" By Matthew J. Davenport: "Cpl. John Baumgarten and Pvt. Mirko Ivosevich of the 7th Field Artillery had come nearly a mile from their artillery battery to reconnect phone lines. 'We were fixing one of F Battery's lines when a 5 inch shell fell about 3 yards from us and instantly killed Pvt. Ivosevich.", Cpl. Baumgarten reported. 'When my pal was hit, we called for a first-aid and a doctor came to his rescue but is was too late as he was taking his last breath." books.google.com/books?id=BS3IBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA255&l... Birth: unknown Death: May 29, 1918 Burial: Somme American Cemetery and Memorial Bony, France www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Ivosev...;

This looks quite similar to a photo that I have of my grandfather. He supposedly was in the 13th cavalry sometime between 1915 and 1920 ish in a unit in west Texas. He died in 1930 when my mom was 5, so I have very little info to go with the very few pictures that belonged to my mom. I don't know much about military history, but I am so curious as to how he went from living in Philadelphia Pennsylvania to fort Clark in Texas to meeting my grandmother in Louisville Kentucky then subsequently marrying and having my mom in Kentucky. Anyway, nice photo, and it is nice to have some history behind this particular photographs.

American ace aviator. From his New York Times obit: "Douglas Campbell, World War I Air Ace And Executive, 94 By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ Published: October 17, 1990 Douglas Campbell, the first American-trained air ace in World War I, who was later a general manager of Pan American Grace Airways, died yesterday at his home in Cos Cob, Conn. He was 94 years old. He died of heart failure, his wife, Virginia, said. Mr. Campbell, a 1917 graduate of Harvard University, joined the Army Air Service just after the United States entered World War I and trained as a pilot in the United States. He was sent to France and after several months of training joined the First Pursuit Group of the 94th Aero Squadron in Toul, France. On April 14, 1918, his first day of combat operations, he shot down his first German plane, an Albatross. A second German plane was shot down in his first dogfight between German pilots and American fliers serving with Gen. John J. Pershing's American Expeditionary Forces. " More at: www.nytimes.com/1990/10/17/obituaries/douglas-campbell-wo...

"Charles "Cy" Rigler (May 16, 1882 – December 21, 1935) was an American umpire in Major League Baseball who worked in the National League from 1906 to 1935. His total of 4,144 games ranked fourth in major league history when he retired, and his 2,468 games as a plate umpire still place him third behind his NL contemporaries Bill Klem (3,543) and Hank O'Day (2,710). Rigler is tied with O'Day for the second most World Series as an umpire (10), trailing only Klem's 18. Rigler has also been credited with instituting the practice of using arm signals when calling balls and strikes." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cy_Rigler

"Charles William "Sandy" Piez (October 13, 1899 – December 29, 1930) was a Major League Baseball player who played for the New York Giants in 1914. He was primarily used as a pinch runner, but also played as an outfielder." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandy_Piez

Back in those days ice cream was big treat. Not kids got enjoy such a pleasure. I remember my dad telling me when he was a child, they only went to town once a week and how he looked forward to the weekend so he could get a coke and the store.

The Japan-British Exhibition took place in 1910: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93British_Exhibition

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_bus_types_used_in_London has a 2006 picture of a similar bus built by the London General Omnibus Company, which introduced bus models in 1909 and 1910. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_General_Omnibus_Company indicates that LGOC acquired the Vanguard company (note company name on side of lower level) in 1908. So the bus pictured here is probably from no later than 1908. www.mercedes-benz.com/en/mercedes-benz/classic/museum/mil... could show the bus model. "Milnes-Daimler double-decker buses saw use in London from 1904 on. The chassis, manufactured at Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft, were furnished with bodies in England and sold by Milnes-Daimler Ltd. 400 in London alone up to 1907. A major customer was Vanguard London Motor Omnibus Co., Ltd., whose logo the exhibited vehicle shows."

That's definitely  the Milnes-Daimler bus.  I don't think they would have put advertising money into the 1910 fair 2 years earlier, so the signs remain a  mystery. Perhaps the newly merged companies co-branded or maybe took years to repaint all the buses?  I don't see any record of an earlier Japan-British Exhibition.

I was assuming that it took time to repaint the buses.  The advertisements may be printed on canvas and attached somehow.  See the snaps or similar where the Waring's sign meets the one for the Japan-British Exhibition.  Waring (later Waring & Gillow) was a furniture store.
The negative has three dates, 1913, 1915 and 1921. LCC on side of tram indicates London County Council. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_County_Council_Tramways

The double-decker tram's route appears to be from Hop Exchange (in Southwark, south of the Thames) to Westminster. On www.tundria.com/trams/GBR/London-1934.shtml see map for Central London. HE (Hop Exchange) has routes 14, 26, which cross the Thames on Blackfriars Bridge (BF), go along the Victoria Embankment and cross back on Westminster Bridge (WB). The single-decker tram will be for another route.

The places listed on the side (see note on image, celebrating Flickr's re-introduction of that feature), on what looks like a replaceable board hanging from hooks or other sort of fixtures are "Clapham Junc[tion], Wandsworth Rd, Vauxhall, Westminster, Embankment near London B[ri]dge." This is also consistent with a section of route 26 as shown on www.tundria.com/trams/GBR/London-1934.shtml (if you check South London map as well as the Central London one).

"Francis Picabia (French: [fʁɑ̃sis pikabja]; born Francis-Marie Martinez de Picabia, 22 January 1879 – 30 November 1953) was a French avant-garde painter, poet and typographist. After experimenting with Impressionism and Pointillism, Picabia became associated with Cubism. His highly abstract planar compositions were colourful and rich in contrasts. He was one of the early major figures of the Dada movement in the United States and in France. He was later briefly associated with Surrealism, but would soon turn his back on the art establishment" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Francis_Picabia

I figured it out. I suspected that many or all of the nitrate negative photos which are in this batch (and much earlier in time than the generally chronological Bain photos LOC posts to Flickr Commons) were from G.G. Bain's own trip to Europe. An article in Editor and Publisher Magazine describes such a trip between May 19 and June, 1910 by Bain that generally matches these photos, including reference to Bain being the guest in Toulon of "F.M. Mansfield (Francis Miltoun) the well known writer. Mr Mansfield is American Consul at Toulon." The article mentions that Bain also went to Cassis. books.google.com/books?id=7yVDAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA121&l... from The Political Graveyard: " Mansfield, Francis Miltoun (b. 1871) — also known as Francis M. Mansfield; Francis Miltoun — of Paris, France. Born in Lynn, Essex County, Mass., February 14, 1871. Newspaper correspondent; author; U.S. Consular Agent in Toulon, 1909-11; U.S. Vice Consul in Barcelona, 1913-14. Burial location unknown. Relatives: Married 1898 to Blanche McManus. " politicalgraveyard.com/bio/mansfield.html U.S. Dept. of State Biographic Register: "Mansfield, Francis Miltoun Born February 14 1871 educated in public and commercial schools of Boston and Washington, author of books on foreign travel for seven years, appointed Consular Agent at Toulon France July 2 1909 " books.google.com/books?id=c_5KAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA2-PA84&am... Francis M. Mansfield wrote under the pseudonym Francis Miltoun, often in books illustrated by his wife, Blanche McManus.

Blanche McManus (Mansfield): " MANSFIELD, Blanche Mc Manus, Mrs Francis Mlltoun Mansfield, care American Consulate Toulon France. Author artist b Feliciana La 1869, dau W McManus, ed In Acad New Orleans and In Paris France, m Francis Mlltoun Mansfield Am Consul Toulon France, Author The American Woman Abroad, Romantic Ireland, Mosques and Minarets, Algeria and Tunisia, and a score of books on foreign life and history. Contributor to the newspaper and magazine press of NY London and Paris. notable illustrator and decorator of de luxe books Recreation: Automobile, touring abroad exclusively. Mem. Touring Club de France (Paris), Touring Club Italiano( Milan) Am Automobile Ass n (NY City) New Vagabonds Club (London)." Woman's Who's who of America: A Biographical Dictionary of Contemporary Women of the United States and Canada, 1914-1915 books.google.com/books?id=aHUEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA538&l... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blanche_McManus I can't find a picture online of Blanche McManus, but it's possible that she is one of the two women pictured.

This series of 23 European pictures were probably taken by George Grantham Bain on his European trip between March and June, 1910. The subjects match up generally with a description of the trip in the June 25, 1910 edition of Editor and Publisher Magazine: "RETURNED WITH ROOSEVELT George Grantham Bain Back After Extensive European Trip George Grantham Bain was on the bridge of the Kaiserin Auguste Victoria with Theodore Roosevelt when that ship arrived at Quarantine, New York. Mr Bain ended a trip not so varied and interesting as Mr Roosevelt's, but full of experience and profit. Sailing from New York March 19 Mr Bain arrived in Naples in time to greet Mr Roosevelt and journey to Rome on his train. After the Rome experience, which was full of interest, Mr Bain went to Florence, Monte Carlo and Toulon, being the guest at the last named city of F.M. Mansfield ("Francis Miltoun"), the well known writer. Mr Mansfield is American Consul at Toulon. After motoring to Hyroes, Cassis, Marseilles and Martigues, Mr Bain went to Paris in time for the reception to Mr Roosevelt at the Elysee Palace. From Paris he went with Mr Roosevelt to Brussels, The Hague, Copenhagen, Christiania, Berlin, London and Cambridge. Mr Bain sent back fourteen letters and more than a hundred photographs illustrating Theodore's Adventures in Wonderland to the Cincinnati Times Star, Louisville Courier Journal, Chicago Record Herald, Portland Oregonian, Cleveland Plain Dealer, Indianapolis Star and other papers. During his absence the Daily Illustrated News Service was in charge of H.W. Sierichs." books.google.com/books?id=7yVDAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA121&l...

LOC has 6 other photos that are also very likely from the set G.G. Bain took while reporting on Roosevelt's trip. These were apparently obtained by LOC as photos, not negatives, and filed in a presidential file for TR called "PRES FILE - Roosevelt, Theodore--In Europe 1910" They are: www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=PRES%20FILE%20-%20Roosevel... Another photo, "Decorations for T. Roosevelt at Brussels", is not in that folder, but seems to be part of the 1910 Bain TR in Europe set: www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/ggbain/item/2010645535/

The first electric tram to operate in The Hague. The picture was taken at railway station Staatsspoor, now called Den Haag Centraal (The Hague Central) and totally different. This tram model was first introduced in 1904 and stayed in service for more than 30 years, after which some of them were sold to Poland. Line 4 went through the Binnenhof (Inner Court) to Loosduinse Brug. Below is a picture of the tram lines through the Binnenhof. The trams had a low roof in order to pass through the gates. Door Onbekend - www.haagsebeeldbank.nl/afbeelding/c0f45efd-315e-49f7-ab9e..., Publiek domein, Link Some more info about the tram can be found here (in Dutch): www.htmfoto.net/algemeen/tonen2.php?pagina=1257853065
Thanks for the additional information.  Do you have any information on the No. 4 streetcar line, or streetcar No. 1?

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Line 4 was electrified on March 4, 1907. Before that it was line D and the tram was horse-drawn. On October 15, 1912 it was lengthened, so this picture was taken between those dates (which corresponds with the comments above).

Tram № 1 was part of a series of 20 trams. In the 1930s they were put out of service. Half of them were sold to Poland (I don't know if № 1 was sold) and № 8 was kept. No tram of that series was saved, but there is a replica, based on a chassis of another old tram. It is kept in the The Hague Tram Museum.

The windows for the tram driver are not original, but a later addition. They have a rather outward position, so there is room for the movement of the control handles.

NYT of June 23, 1918 reports the donation of a pony and cart to the American Fund for French Wounded.  The pony, named General Joffre, was to be exhibited next week by little Miss Gertrude Taylor on Fifth Avenue.

"OBITUARY: CAPT. JAMES A. ANDERSON, OF SUMMIT, KILLED WHILE ENGAGED IN BATTLE IN FRANCE. Hon. Joe S. Anderson, of Summit, was notified Saturday of the death of his son, Capt. James A. Anderson, who was killed while leading his company of 127 men over the top in France, on May 28th. Capt. Anderson was 30 years old May 21st. He enlisted in the volunteer reserve corps when he was 19, and served three years, having seen service in Panama. He went to Mexico during the trouble down there as a second lietenant and after returning from there he left the army for a short while, but re-enlisted with the regular army, and in 1914 he stood examination for a commission and sent to FortJay, New York. He went to France with General Pershing's expeditionary forces and was said to be the first American soldier to set foot on No Man's Land. He was here made a captain and placed in command of a company of the 28th Inf. and was leading this company in battle when killed. His record on the other side was so brilliant that he had been nominated by General Pershing to be a major, and the senate just previous to his death had confirmed the nomination. Capt. Anderson was cited for gallantry in action and had been given a 28-day furlough. He had only returned to his command a few days when he was killed. Capt. Anderson stood very high as a military man and as an officer and undoubtedly had a bright future before him. Surviving Capt. Anderson are his father, Joseph S. Anderson, of Summit, two brothers, Ernest Anderson, of North Augusta, and Dr. Paul Anderson of Summit and seven sisters, Mrs. GE Usher of Adel, Ga; Mrs. JS Vandiver of Ochlocknee, Ga; Mrs. GS Pryor, of Leesburg, Ga; Misses Maybelle and Eylau Anderson, teachers in the Brunswick city schools, Miss Cora Anderson in YWCA work in Blue Ridge, NC, and Miss Grace Anderson, who received her diploma at the ECI Summit-Graymont this week. Printed in SFB 6-13-1918." archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/GAEMANUE/2005-07/1...

Rufus Ford Montgall (1887-1918), Kansas City, Mo., Killed in Action, May 30, 1918. This photo accompanied an account of Capt. Montgall's life in the June 25, 1918 edition of Lumber World Review: "TRIBUTE TO THE LATE CAPTAIN RF MONTGALL Captain Rufus F Montgall age 31 connected with the American Sash & Door Co Kansas City Mo and a member of Pershlng's staff on the French front was killed by a bomb dropped from an aeroplane just before midnight on the evening of Memorial Day, May 30. Captain Montgall with Col Bertrand T Clayton and Captain Harry A Bullock were occupied at their headquarters in an abandoned chateau miles behind the fighting line when an aeroplane dropped a bomb on the chateau and killed the three men , all of whom were associated with quartermaster's department, Col Clayton being division quartermaster. A touching tribute to the late Capt is made by his one time employer and associate Frank J Moss, president of the American & Door Co who as the deceased young man frequently said, was "the only father he had known", and whom Mr Moss refers to as "as dear to me as a son". [more at books.google.com/books?id=MOQoAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA11-PA46&a... He has a memorial in a Kansas City Cemetery. His grave is in the Somme American Cemetery and Memorial, Bony, France. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Montga...; www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=montga...;

Herman Bernstein (September 21, 1876 – August 31, 1935) was an American journalist, poet, novelist, playwright, translator, Jewish activist, and diplomat. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Bernstein

Bernstein was in the news when he returned on June 23, 1918 to New York from a trip to Russia: "FINDS INTERVENTION RUSSIA'S ONLY HOPE; Herman Bernstein Says Nine Tenths of the Nation Would Welcome Allied Expedition. GERMANS GETTING CONTROL Russian People Are Demoralized and Desperate--Bread Is $2.50 a Pound in Petrograd. Expect Allies to Come. Engineer wants Intervention. Herman Bernstein, editor of The American Hebrew, returned yesterday from a trip to Russia, where he went last January to study conditions. He arrived here fully convinced that unless the Allies took immediate action by intervening to save Russia from the Germans they would lose the war." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9407E1DC173EE4...

This event took place on Flag Day in 1918, June 14th. The Giants, who had won the National League pennant the year before, ran it up the Polo Grounds flagpole before a game with the Chicago Cubs. From a colorful account of the game: "M'GRAW'S BATSMAN FALL UPON VAUGHAN AND COVER BRUINS WITH WHITEWASH; HAUGHTY CUBS ARE HUMBLED BY GIANTS McGraw's Men Celebrate Flag Day by Taking Final Game of the Series, 7 to 0. DEMAREE IN FINE FORM Holds Chicago Batsmen Helpless While the New Yorkers Are Flaying Vaughn's Curves. For fear that some people might have forgotten that the Giants won the National League pennant last season, Flag Day was celebrated up at the Polo Grounds yesterday, Old Glory and the championship muslin being run up the flag pole on the same rope." query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E0CEED9103BEE...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bevo "Bevo was a non-alcoholic malt beverage, or near beer, brewed in the United States by the Anheuser-Busch company beginning in the early 20th century. Bevo enjoyed its greatest success during the time of prohibition, when beer, wine and distilled liquors, were made illegal for thirteen years. The Anheuser-Busch company started brewing Bevo when alcoholic beverages were prohibited in 1916 by the United States armed forces. Production rose greatly with national prohibition in 1919, and Bevo was by far the most popular of the many "cereal beverages" or "near beers" of the time."

The Tanglefoot ad (for flypaper) was a clever baseball ad campaign, customized for different teams and ballparks. "Leslie Mann (November 18, 1892 – January 14, 1962), was a college football player, professional baseball player and football and basketball coach. He played outfield in the Major Leagues from 1913 to 1928. He played for the Boston Braves, St. Louis Cardinals, Cincinnati Reds, New York Giants, and Chicago Cubs. He compiled a career record of 43–30 in five seasons as a head basketball coach." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leslie_Mann_(athlete)

LOC: SABR Pictorial History Committee has dated this photo 1916, probably because that was the last season Knabe played baseball, as a Chicago Cub. However... "Cubs manager Fred Mitchell brought Knabe back to the majors in 1918 as a coach. Chicago won the pennant and faced the Red Sox in the World Series. From behind the third base line, Knabe and his Boston counterpart, Heinie Wagner, both verbally rode the opposition and each other. Between innings in Game Two, Knabe insulted Wagner to a breaking point, and the two coaches engaged in a “private brawl” under the Comiskey Park grandstands.38 Knabe got the better of the scrap, but the Red Sox got the better of the Cubs, taking the Series in six games. Knabe stayed with the Cubs through August 1919." sabr.org/bioproj/person/310d7ec8 Given the surrounding shots of other Cubs at the Polo Grounds in June, 1918, and that Knabe is wearing the distinctive 1918 road uniform of the Cubs, they will probably want to correct the date to 1918. exhibits.baseballhalloffame.org/dressed_to_the_nines/unif...
Thanks to AS for further research, and to SABR for concurring. We will correct the date to 1918.

"James Leslie "Hippo" Vaughn (April 9, 1888 – May 29, 1966) was an American left-handed pitcher in Major League Baseball for the Chicago Cubs during the 1910s. He had some good years for the Cubs during a time when they were not always competitive, winning over 20 games in five seasons, including a National League-leading 22 in 1918, when the season was ended a month early due to government restrictions brought about by World War I. USS Comfort (AH-3) was a hospital ship for the United States Navy in World War I. She was the sister ship of USS Mercy (AH-4) but the two ships were not of a ship class. Comfort was known as SS Havana in passenger service for the Ward Line, and as USAT Havana in United States Army service before her Navy service. Her name was restored to Havana in 1927, and she was renamed SS Yucatán in 1935, and SS Agwileon in 1941. In World War II, she was known as USAT Agwileon and USAHS Shamrock in service for the United States Army. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Comfort_(AH-3)

Stokes stretcher.. Still in use: "A Stokes basket, also called a Stokes stretcher or Stokes litter, is a metal wire or plastic litter widely used in search and rescue. Its key feature is that it can be disassembled for transport in backpacks or by pack horse. Originally designed by Charles Francis Stokes, these baskets have been notorious for spinning under the downdraft from the rotating helicopter blades." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Litter_(rescue_basket)#Stokes_basket Admiral Stokes, the inventor: "Rear Admiral Stokes served in the Navy from 1889 until 1917 when he retired. His duties carried him to Cuba during the Spanish-American War, to the Orient during the Boxer Rebellion and the Philippines during the insurrection. He was a pioneer in abdominal surgery and devised the first-aid dressing which the Army and Navy used in modified form during the World War. He also devised the Stokes splinter stretcher." www.arlingtoncemetery.net/cfstokes.htm

"Cdr. Wells" is a mystery, though it seems as though his 4 stripes and a star signfies he was a captain. www.public.navy.mil/bupers-npc/support/uniforms/uniformre...
This type of insignia www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05/27241168910/ belongs to the uniform of a captain of the Royal Naval Reserve, s. www.naval-history.net/WW2aaRN-PayTables00Ranks-Badges.htm

A Commander Wells of the Royal Navy, representing Great Britain appeared several times in the newspapers, e.g. - The sun., June 01, 1918, Page 7, col. 5, "Butler Tells of Entente" chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1918-06-01/ed-... - New-York tribune., September 06, 1918, Page 12, col. 7, "Many Countries Represented" chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-09-06/ed-... In the New-York tribune., June 01, 1918, Page 4, col. 6, he is named R. N. Wells chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-06-01/ed-... (PS: but probably R.N. stands for Royal Navy)

On the other hand, he could be Captain Lionel Del Wells "DEL WELLS, LIONEL Synopsis: The President of the United States takes pleasure in presenting the Navy Distinguished Service Medal to Lionel Del Wells, Captain, British Royal Navy, for exceptionally meritorious and distinguished service in a position of great responsibility to the Government of the United States, as member of an Allied Force during World War I." (www.homeofheroes.com/members/03_DSM/navy/citations/01_ww1...) It was the 25th anniversary for the class of 1893 at the 1918 Columbia commencement ceremony. For the occasion, they donated a bell for St. Paul's Chapel on the campus, which was recognized in a ceremony on commencement day. About the gift: "St. Paul’s also has a beautifully voiced bronze bell, donated in 1918 by the Class of 1893. The bell, still rung manually, calls the University community to many of its most significant gatherings. Cast by Meneely and Company of Troy, New York, the bell bears the inscription “To Ring Out Through The Ages For Truth Justice and Liberty.” ouc.columbia.edu/st-pauls-chapel/

"8641  THE FLAPPER FAN IN USE.  A gas wave coming over the trench,  the men using the fan to clear the trench of gas.  Training at Camp Kearney Cal "

Catalogue of Photographs and Stereopticon Slides
United States. Committee on Public Information. Division of pictures
March 1 to June 1, 1918

A youtube video shows the fan in use. "In the trenches, mustard gas and other agents were counteracted in a variety of ways. Once an attack ceased, trenches were cleared of low lying gas. One method required the use of an Ayrton or trench fan. This device consisted of a two-foot-long handle attached to a rigid piece of canvas hinged to a fifteen-inch section that moved in one direction. In effect the fan was used like a shovel, with the moveable flap creating an upward air current, thus removing the gas. Americans adopted these fans as called for by British defensive gas doctrine. Unfortunately, the fans, according to the British were "worse than worthless." Not only did they not remove the vapor, but the exertion of masked users led to exhaustion and increased susceptibility to gassing. The fans were eventually discarded and burned to create an updraft, soon recognized as a better method of clearing trenches and dugouts of gas." www.youtube.com/watch?v=C_2Dt1-shPY The Imperial War Museum has one: www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/30028501

"On February 15, 1918, at a military airfield outside of Fort Worth, Texas, his plane stalled during a climb and roll maneuver. (Vernon was trying to avoid crashing into another cadet-piloted plane.) Vernon was only 75 feet in the air, but he had given the safer rear seat to his student, and died when the plane fell nose first into the ground. According to the monument at the crash site, "Neither the other pilot, his student cadet, nor Vernon's pet monkey, Jeffrey, were seriously injured." Peyton Conway March (born December 27, 1864 in Easton, Pennsylvania – April 13, 1955) was an American soldier and Army Chief of Staff. He is largely responsible for the designing the powerful role of the Chief of Staff in the 20th century. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peyton_C._March

www.arlingtoncemetery.net/pcmarch.htm is his record at Arlington Cemetery. "He was promoted to temporary General, May 1918 and was Chief of Staff of the United States Army, 19 May 1918–30 June 1921. "

NYT of May 25, 1918 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9902E6DF123FE432A... indicated that his nomination was confirmed by the Senate on May 24, 1918.

Major General George Owen Squier (March 21, 1865 – March 24, 1934) was born in Dryden, Michigan, United States.[1] He graduated from the United States Military Academy in the Class of 1887 and received a Ph.D. from Johns Hopkins University in 1893. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Owen_Squier
See

www.arlingtoncemetery.net/gosquier.htm is his record at Arlington Cemetery. "As Chief Signal Officer during World War I, Squier was responsible not only for radio, but also was charged with the entire aviation and communications mission of the United States Army. During the war, Squier succeeded in opening two great Army laboratories one at Fort Monmouth for radio and another at Langley Field, Virginia, for aviation. Squier can be credited with the Army's institutionalization of scientific research and development for military purposes." "Shortly before his retirement in 1924, Squier turned his attention to a new application of the transmission technologies he helped to develop: piped-in music. His idea led to the establishment in 1922 of the music service Wired Radio, which is much better known by its present name, given it by Squier shortly before his death: Muzak."

Date on negative, 5-27-18.The buffalo head on the wall and buffalo insignia on the door on the stage probably mark this as a facility of the "Buffalo Soldiers", segregated African-American units of the military.

Thanks Art Siegel for noticing the buffalo head on the wall and the insignia. This is probably the "Buffalo Auditorium" which was built and paid for by the African American 367th Infantry (sometimes known as the Buffalo Soldiers) stationed at Camp Upton. All soldiers at the camp used the facility for training and recreation. The 367th regiment coat of arms, an image of the exterior of the auditorium, and more information can be found here: babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=loc.ark:/13960/t4wh32p21;v... and here: babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=coo.31924066373329;view=1u...

Perhaps en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_MacLane 'Mary MacLane (May 1, 1881 — c. August 6, 1929) was a controversial Canadian-born American writer whose frank memoirs helped usher in the confessional style of autobiographical writing. MacLane was known as the "Wild Woman of Butte".'

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] Hello swanq. I am Mary MacLane's biographer (work in progress) and somewhat her rediscoverer in the 1980s and 1990s - published the first anthology of her work ever, "Tender Darkness" (Abernathy & Brown, 1993). Yes, that is exactly who this picture is. A still from her pioneering silent movie en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Men_Who_Have_Made_Love_to_Me . Apparently lost, but we are searching for it. I have subtitles and a number of photos and the text on which the movie was based, but not a second of it has ever turned up. In this photo, the irrepressible Mary is returning a wedding ring held in her hand to a swain. In some versions of the photo, he is visible and looks quite disappointed. Mary's writing - three books, several dozen newspaper features, and a hundred private letters and telegrams or so - is a world unto itself, and after thirty years it still fascinates me. Looking forward to telling the world more about her.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/143376647@N06] : Thank you so much for confirming the identification.  Best of luck with your biography.

Michael Brown:  Thank you for your confirmation of swanq's information and for telling us that this image is from Mary MacLane's lost movie, "Men Who Have Made Love to Me."  Good luck with your biography and  search for the film. We will add more details to the description of this image when we update.

"The Victor Company, following its usual custom of responding to these drives, staged a concert in the Auditorium of their Executive Office Building in the evening of May 25th, in behalf of the Red Cross. Third from right in front row of parade, with top hat, is President Woodrow Wilson. The plans had been for him to to review the parade, but he decided to join the march. Next to him is Major General George R Dyer of the New York State Guard. See NYT of May 19, 1918 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E5DA103BEE3AB... Thanks to B-59 for correction on the General's initials -- now fixed.

I think the building behind the clock is still there. See streetview at www.google.com/maps/@40.7646991,-73.9727144,3a,75y,22.02h... That building is at the northeast corner of the intersection of Fifth Avenue and East 60th Street. That means the photo is taken from somewhere near the Plaza Hotel. The building with the large Red Cross flag must be where the Sherry-Netherland Building (built in 1927) now is. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sherry-Netherland The Wikipedia article indicates that the site had previously been occupied by the New Netherland Hotel. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotel_New_Netherland For more about the New Netherlands Hotel, see daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2014/07/the-lost-new-nethe...

According to The sun., May 26, 1918, Section 4 Pictorial Magazine, Image 33 (photo) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1918-05-26/ed-... the General next to Pres. Wilson is George R. Dyer. The man on the other side is Wilson's private secretary J. P. Tumulty (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Patrick_Tumulty).

Just north of the New Netherlands is a store sign reading Max Schling. Schling had a florist store at 785 Fifth Avenue for a while. See an ad near the top of a guide from the New York Botanical Garden at libguides.nybg.org/content.php?pid=550344&sid=5451458

The building that is still there is the Metropolitan Club (1 E 60th St.). See www.metropolitanclubnyc.org/default.aspx%3Fp%3DDynamicMod... Beyond it is the Gerry mansion, demolished in 1929. Plans released in 1892 said that it would be "a combination of French, Gothic and Renaissance." See daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2012/06/lost-elbridge-t-ge... And the building this side of 60th street (near the street clock), is the Van Norden Trust Building, designed by Henry J. Hardenbergh. From www.startsandfits.com/hardenbergh/ : "The Van Norden Trust Co. Building, an ornate nine-story apartment buiding at 787 Fifth Avenue, at the southeast corner of 60th Street, built in 1903 and demolished c. 1961." See collections.mcny.org/Collection/5th-Avenue-at-the-S.E.-co...

As for the clock, I've been unable to find anything about it. It looks to have four faces and be on an arch structure that also has spherical lights. I find it in dcmny.org/islandora/object/photosnycbeyond%3A20332 but the photo is undated. Its in collections.mcny.org/Collection/Hotels%20Netherland%20and... dated circa 1910. But not in www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3c27133/ submitted for copyright in 1905. As far as I can judge, it should be visible in this view. A subway station opened at that intersection in the summer of 1919. See NYT of August 31, 1919 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E0CE0DD153AEF33A... Perhaps the clock was removed then.

The Smithsonian has a print [arago.si.edu/record_194367_img_1.html] of this, captioned "New York City Postmaster Thomas Patten is photographed handing Lt. Torrey Webb equipment to make ready for one of the first regularly scheduled airmail flights in the United States. On May 15, 1918, the United States officially established airmail service between New York, Philadelphia, and Washington, DC, under the direction of the Post Office Department, using army aircraft and pilots. The Army Air Corps pilots chosen to fly that day were Lieutenants Howard Culver, Torrey Webb, Walter Miller and Stephen Bonsal. Lt. Webb carried the first day’s mail in this Curtiss "Jenny" aircraft numbered 38278 from a temporary airmail field at Belmont Park, Long Island, New York to Bustleton Field, near Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. " and dated May 15, 1918.
This sequence of photos is related to the first scheduled airmail route. See www.aerofiles.com/airmail.html for details.
Torrey Hord Webb (7 December 1892 - 23 November 1975) and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_G._Patten

Date on negative is 5/15/18. From postalmuseum.si.edu/airmail/pilot/pilot_army/pilot_army_c... "After graduating from Columbia and serving in the army, Lieutenant Torrey Webb completed his aviation training at Ellington Field, where he came to Major Fleet's attention. His good record spoke well for him, and Fleet hired him for the airmail service. Webb flew over 3,500 miles as an airmail pilot, spending 45 hours in the air. As did Culver, Webb suffered only one forced landing in his airmail career." See also earlyaviators.com/ewebbtor.htm Notice the map attached to his leg!

From Riggin's NYT obituary: "Aileen Riggin Soule, a diver and swimmer who at age 14 became the youngest American Olympic gold medalist and later became the oldest living American female gold medalist, died Thursday in a nursing home in Honolulu. She was 96. At the 1920 Olympics in Antwerp, Belgium, Riggin won the first gold medal awarded in women's springboard diving and became, at 4 feet 7 inches and 65 pounds, the smallest American Olympic champion. In the 1924 Olympic Games in Paris, she became the only woman to win medals in swimming and diving in the same Olympics, taking the silver medal in springboard diving and the bronze medal in the 100-meter backstroke." www.nytimes.com/2002/10/21/sports/aileen-riggin-soule-oly...

While on tour in the United States, Paderewski fell ill on June 27, 1941. He died of pneumonia in New York City two days later. His remains were temporary interred within the USS Maine Mast Memorial in Arlington National Cemetery near Washington, D.C. After the fall of communism, his body was brought to Warsaw in 1992 and permanently laid to rest in St. John's Archcathedral. Two markers remain at Arlington National Cemetery marking the temporary repose of Paderewski's body. One is outside the memorial, near the stairs leading up to the memorial plaza. The other is inside the memorial, where his remains once lay. flic.kr/p/e3Umr8

A history of the brief life of the Nobile N-3: "Nobile N-3: The [Japanese] Navy's first semi-rigid type, the N-3 was almost 263ft long with a maximum diameter of 49ft and a hydrogen capacity of 274,700ft 3 . It was powered by two Maybach 245hp six cylinder in-line water-cooled engines, each driving a two bladed pusher propeller, mounted in streamlined nacelles abreast of each other below, close to and about half way along the envelope. A well glazed enclosed cabin for the crew of 7/12 was fixed direct to and almost at the front of the envelope keel, with horizontal stabilisers and dorsal/ventral rudders at the envelope rear for flight control. It had a range of 1250 miles at a cruising speed of about 60mph. The N-3 arrived in Japan during January 1927 and was assembled in the Zeppelin shed at Kasumigaura by Maj.Gen.Umberto Nobile and a team of Italian technicians. It made a successful first flight on 6 th April with a crew of six Japanese and six Italians, after which it operated satisfactorily and joined naval manoeuvres south of Tokyo on 22 nd October 1927. Unfortunately strong winds resulted in an emergency landing on Kozu-shima Island, where all the crew managed to disembark. After they had done so a sudden gust of wind carried the airship out to sea, where it exploded and was totally destroyed. Its one claim to fame was in being the fastest Japanese airship." www.j-aircraft.com/research/jas_jottings/japanese_airship...

Like other Junkers types, it was an all-metal, low-wing cantilever monoplane. Compared to modern aircraft, only the corrugated duralumin metal skin, so typical for Junkers aircraft, seems unusual. Band is Patrick Conway's Band. See notes with

Band is Conway's Band, according to NYT of April 13, 1918 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D0DE0DD1F38E533A... See digital.lib.umd.edu/archivesum/actions.DisplayEADDoc.do;j... for finding aid to archival collection of papers of Patrick Conway. "Patrick ("Patsy") Conway was a prominent band leader in the early 20th Century. While a music teacher at Cornell University, he organized and directed the Ithaca Band, which later became known as Patrick Conway and His Band around 1908. During the summer season Conway's band toured the mid-western and western United States performing at state fairs and expositions, including the Panama-Pacific Exposition in 1915, and had regular engagements at Willow Grove Park, Philadelphia, and Young's Pier, Atlantic City. After serving in the First World War, Conway returned to Ithaca and founded the Military Band School as an affiliate of the Ithaca Conservatory of Music. He taught at the school from 1922 until his death in 1929."

Warbasse, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Peter Warbasse of 384 Washington Ave. and Woods Hole, Mass. Miss Glave is of English parentage. On the maternal side her great-great-grandmother was the daughter of Viscount Buttenant, Earl of Barrymore. who married Henry Holland of Holland House, London, and her maternal grandfather was D. W. Howard Haywood, descendant of the Duke of Norfolk Howards. She is a niece of the late E. J. Glave, explorer, writer and lecturer, who was one of Sir Henry M. Stanley's pioneers in Africa, a member of the Arkwell expedition in Canada and who explored and lectured on Alaska. Miss Glave was graduated from St. Mary's School, Peekskill, and took a postgraduate course at the Todhunter School in Manhattan. She is a member of the Junior League of New York. I think I have the Hollins family sorted out. Three of the children on the wall appear to be grandchildren of Harry Bowly Hollins (1854-1938) My conclusions: At left is Bobby (Robert) with cousin Gerald next to him. Gerald's sister Faith comes next. Bobby's older sister, Hope, is in a nearby photo on her pony Pebbles. Various snippets of evidence below. Some kind of exposure system in hand ?

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/garww] : He's holding the actual tintype print. The tintype print is a "direct positive on a thin sheet of metal coated with a dark lacquer or enamel and used as the support for the photographic emulsion." (See Wikipedia.) Inside the camera, there was a small drawer that held several unexposed sheets. Using a long black silk sock in the back of the camera, the photographer would reach into the drawer, pull out a single sheet and position it to make the picture. Once exposed, he reaches in again and slides the sheet into a monobath that's held in a metal can made into the back underside of the camera. Look closely and you can see it hanging from the back of the camera here, although most of it is obscured from view. He would wait the appropriate time and then rotate the container so that the sheet could be retrieved through a small trap door it the tanks top at the back of the camera. A simple wash with water (see his bucket?) removed any remaining chemistry and brought out the image. Here, he appears to be holding it to dry. Normally it was then placed in a cardboard frame for the customer. Per this ad for one of the Daydark cameras (historiccamera.com/cgi-bin/librarium2/pm.cgi?action=app_d...;) you could make 500% markup and they had reports of people earning $10 to $12 a DAY! (In 1910...) [grin]
Fascinating. What a great image of a photo maker!

One can easily duplicate the tintype look in Photoshop.
What fascinates me is what the image structure is saying – near center, the camera technology being examined/ discussed; far center, the large white guy with his back to the activity.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/22549175@N02] :  Sorry, but you really can't 'duplicate' the look of a real tintype in Photoshop.  And that hits on part of your other observation.  People were fascinated with the "instant" image from the photographer.  Because the emulsion was on top of the metal sheet,  I could fully see that as he's drying it, he's also tilting it in the light and the gentleman over his shoulder is studying the almost "3D" quality that the surface of a tintype has.

And as far as the guy with his back to the group--he's just walking away (see the position of his legs).  I wouldn't read anything more about him in the photo other than he was part of the background.  Remember--these are street photographers from the 1910's-1930's.  Downtown was the like the mall today and you'd have lots of people around at any given time.  And these photographers were common--sometime too much so.   In the town where I grew up--Chattanooga, Tennessee--it got to be such a problem with so many street photographers getting pushy to ply their trade downtown that the city made it illegal to TAKE a photo on Market Street (the main road thru town).  I'm not sure if it's still on the books today, but as late as the 1980's it was still a "blue law" on the books.  Obviously the city fathers of the early 20th century never envisioned smartphones with their cameras of the 21st century...  [grin]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/captkodak/]
“…you really can't 'duplicate' the look of a real tintype in Photoshop…”
Of course I agree, ink on paper or a back-illuminated screen can’t look exactly the same as any of the chemical processes, including a collodion process – but PS is working on 3-D effects.
“Obviously the city fathers of the early 20th century never envisioned….”
Undoubtedly they could ban a business operation, but photographing is protected: “To achieve First Amendment protection, a plaintiff must show that he possessed: (1) a message to be communicated; and (2) an audience to receive that message, regardless of the medium in which the message is to be expressed.”
Here’s the message:
The center-of-influence is the camera. A camera is a device that produces a document. In the case of a portrait, that document signifies identity.
The group of African-American men is on either side of the center-of-influence. A triangle forms from them to the LARGE white man, back turned, and walking away.
The reading would be that African Americans formed their group identity in that way – separate from the larger white majority.

In that structural reading was perhaps a reality in American culture.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/22549175@N02] :Wow!  You made quite the jump there.  I really can't tell the ethnicity of the man walking away.  But if that suit the narrative you want to make up about the photo, go with it.  What I see is a street photographer doing what so many did during that time frame.  Shoot the photo, show it to the subject and generate excitement from the crowd that gathers to watch the making of this "instant" photo--all to get yet another customer.  He's making a living.  It's salesmanship.  Every culture and every ethnicity has someone who fills that roll.  Sometimes, it's really not about race...

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/eclecticdesigner] :  I didn't say it was a "point & shoot" camera.  Just that it wasn't another Daydark camera or a view camera of the era.  

I've been doing freelance work off and on for almost 40 years, I use to sell cameras in a camera shop, I've taught photography for civic groups and summer camps, I have a fridge at home just for my film and over 250 cameras in my collection.  And, yes, have a darkroom.  The "tech" of cameras and photography is a hobby of mine along with a fascination of history.   So I'm not the "only one educated in photography" but I think I have somewhat of an understanding of it.  So before we start the name calling, I'm just here to share like most people are.  I have a fascination of street photographers and their tools.  Part of this is because one of my favorite photos I have of my parents was shot by a street photographer when they were dating teenagers:

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/captkodak/3502654410]

(Mom hated this photo because of the guy "checking her out" over her shoulder.  [grin])  This photo was made in the 30's.  The street photographers then would shoot a candid of you as you walked down the street and then chase you down and try to sell it to you.
I don't understand why the tintype look can't be done in Photoshop. I thought Photoshop could create any kind of effect.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/7185088@N07] :  Photoshop (and many of the plug-ins you can get for it) will do a tintype look, but if you've seen a real tintype, you can immediately spot the difference.  For example, if I took a tintype, scanned it, and then printed it with contemporary printing methods and then produced a similar image out of Photoshop, both finished photos would look very similar.  However, if I compared the scanned/printed image to the original tintype, you would see that the new image misses a "sheen" in the blacks (which is the lacquer base of the image) and the image is "flat" while the true tintype has a raised emulsion--making it look almost like an engraving.  

So the issue is not as much what Photoshop can and cannot do, but how the final printed image is made.  You know--many of the print houses now produced metal prints which are actually printed on metal substrates.  I wonder if any of them have experimented with taking a tintype "look" image and producing a more realistic looking print.  That might be the technology that could best simulate it.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/barbara_loc] :  Thanks for that post.  The camera in that image appears to be a 4x5 field camera (possibly a Graflex based on the rangefinder viewfinder on the side and the flash handle on the other side--but we're looking at it from the back and it's hard to tell for sure).  And while you can get backs that adapter for 2-1/4x2-1/4 film, based on the clean edge of the image above, I would believe he shot it with a smaller camera.  The info on that shot indicates he's the photographer and it's from a 35mm negative.   35mm cameras were introduced in the mid 20's, but began to gain mainstream popularity right before WWII as new features--like self timers--became available on the cameras for the first time.  So it's actually possible he set up that shot and then made a "selfie".  [grin]

A point of note:  He would have been 22 or 23 years old in that photo.  I can only imagine the body of work he amassed in his role as a Farm Security Administration photographer!

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/31580040@N04/] Have to disagree with you again my friend. I was a nine-ball player for almost twenty years and been around pool halls and major pool and billiard tournaments a large part of my life. In my youth I played snooker primarily in preparation of hustling (on what we termed, "slop tables" (8-ball pool). Regulation Snooker tables are genuinely known as 12' x 6' tables (actual playing surface: 11'-8.5" x 5-10") and they most definitely do have pockets, albeit, pockets smaller than a normal pool table (because snooker uses smaller balls). Additionally the pockets on a snooker table are not crescent shaped as on a normal pool table, making it more difficult to sink a ball especially when shooing from narrow angles. A player usually has to apply "english" (spin) on both, the cue ball which interacts with the object ball in order to sink difficult shots like these. Twenty-two balls are used in the game of snooker: 15 red balls, 6 numbered balls and of course, a cue ball. Although "true billiards" a/k/a "English billiards is sometimes played on a pool table with pockets (as may be the case in the picture above) but this would not be considered regulation three-corner billiards and in no case would tournament billiards (nor any "big money") billiards games be played on any table containing pockets. Some confusion exists because over time, the terms, "billiards" and "pool" have been used synonymously when in fact billiards and pool are two totally different types of games. The rules of the game of "9-ball pool" are rather complex and I will not attempt to explain in this forum. These can be found here - www.wpa-pool.com/web/index.asp?id=117&; Hope this clarifies everything.

It's probably the lack of pool tables in the UK influencing me. The pockets are obvious in this picture en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_billiards#/media/File:Billi... from 1899. The sport is run by the World Professional Billiards and Snooker Association and the rules are the ones agreed in 1899, with minor changes. I still have a half size snooker table in my garage.

In the case of Bain photos of subjects from the 1920's (usually 1924 or later) , the negative catalog number is frequently (but not always) at the end of the numerical sequence and often above 10. For instance, this photo 4546-16, is one of the last 3 numbers in the 4546 series, 15, 16, and 17, which are all from 1927 (the earlier ones in the 4546 series being from 1918). Why Bain decided to essentially "reuse" 4546 and other series in the 1920's is a mystery. see www.flickr.com/search/?sort=date-taken-desc&safe_sear... for 70 other examples of 1927 subjects. A little more of the Emporia Gazette article, extrapolated from very bad OCR: "Preparatory to the actual modeling the young sculptor had been given the freedom of American embassy to study Lindbergh perhaps more than any other has, but since the bust was to be a surprise, actual posing was impossible. de Paris therefore experimented with a new method of portrait study which he believes will completely eliminate the tedious poses which made portraiture in the past so difficult a task. He photographed Lindbergh with the slow motion [...] to help him get the character "

Field Marshal Douglas Haig, 1st Earl Haig, KT, GCB, OM, GCVO, KCIE, ADC (19 June 1861 – 29 January 1928) was a senior officer of the British Army. During the First World War he commanded the British Expeditionary Force (BEF) on the Western Front from late 1915 until the end of the war. He was commander during the Battle of the Somme, the battle with one of the highest casualties in British military history, the Third Battle of Ypres, and the Hundred Days Offensive, which led to the armistice of 11 November 1918. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_Haig,_1st_Earl_Haig

Date written on negative is 3/12/18 New-York tribune., March 13, 1918, Page 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-03-13/ed-... has a similar picture, captioned, "One thousand recruits from the Pelham Bay Naval Training Station yesterday showed New York how they look in full equipment. The men are here for the big military and naval meet and ball at Madison Square Garden." Also stated, "They arranged to have two parades. New York saw the first yesterday. Down Fifth Avenue from Fifty-ninth Street to Twenty-sixth Street, and then east to the 69th Regiment Armory, at Lexington Avenue, swung a thousand naval reserves." The bigger parade, with other military and police units, etc. as well as these sailors, was to be on March 14 and go along Fifth Avenue in the other direction, starting at the battleship Recruit in Union Square.
See Pacific Marine Review, Volume 15, August 1918 books.google.com/books?id=aYc9AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA7-PA112&a... for a piece on the training station.

Thanks for the information swanq and TVL1970. After looking through some newspapers, I believe this is a parade that took place on March 12th, 1918. The trainees at the Pelham Bay Naval Training Station and marched down 5th Avenue to Madison Square Garden where the Naval and Military Meet was held. We'll update our catalog record.

Rodney "Gipsy" Smith MBE (31 March 1860 – 4 August 1947) was a British evangelist who conducted evangelistic campaigns in the United States and Great Britain for over 70 years. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quimper Unlike the other pictures of France in the Bain stream from this period, this is not from the battle-scarred western front, but from Brittany. According to worldatwar.net/article/brittany/, "A million Bretons answered the French call to arms in World War I. A quarter of them never returned. Bretons were killed and wounded at a rate twice the national average." Quimper is not too far from Brest, the main debarkation port for American troops in 1918. This is the church of St. Denis at Sommesous: "The construction of the church dates back to 11th century Sommesous. Built in chalk and stone size around Vertus, it is Romanesque and classified as a historical monument in 1855. The portal is semicircular and has a herringbone design. The exterior of the apse is decorated with small arcades under the cornice. The apse is vaulted cul-de-four and has windows with columns and capitals. Inside, the church is divided into three naves by pillars rows. There are two side altars, the first is dedicated to Saint Denis, one on the right is dedicated to the Virgin. Notice the curious capitals of the transept." (via Google Translate) chalons.catholique.fr/eglises/sommesous-eglise-saint-denis/

This is an Agence Meurisse photo, dated 1914. It is online at the Bibliothèque nationale de France site, Gallica. Meurisse with the caption "Sommesons : l'église entièrement brûlée" (the burned church). gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b9042357v.r=55188 There are as well other references to the town as Sommesons. A wonderful bit of history and culture.  The basket net seems to be closed into a pouch - the ball won't fall through.  Could this be?

"The peach basket hoop was replaced by a metal rim and netting about a decade after the sport was invented. The netting was closed at the bottom, so much like the peach basket, players had to climb up and retrieve the ball from the net each time someone scored. However, by 1906, the bottom of the net was cut out to allow the ball to fall through the hoop." www.livestrong.com/article/363009-the-basketball-hoop-a-h... A more perplexing question is the orientation of the hoop, and how, and to what it is affixed.
Bloomers, and looser corsets, were the beginning of the liberation of women.  Finally, they could move!
As for their form, the biggest restriction was the film speed, and the game was still in its infancy before 1906.

From The Sun's story on the May 28, 1918 event for the 307th regimental family unit, cited above: "A garden party for the benefit of the soldiers of the 307th Regiment and their families will be held in Gramercy Park on Tuesday afternoon. This is the only private park within the city limits, and as far as is known it has not opened at any time in its history for such a purpose. Mrs. Wallston Hill Brown, Mrs. Walter Graeme Eliot, Mrs. Lewis B. Woodruff and Miss Grace Bigelow are among the members of the committee." Anna Fitziu (April 1, 1887 – April 20, 1967) was an American soprano who had a prolific international opera career during the early part of the 20th century.[1] Her signature roles included Fiora in L'amore dei tre re, Mimi in La Boheme, Nedda in Pagliacci, and the title roles in Isabeau, Madama Butterfly, and Tosca. After her singing career ended, she embarked on a second career as a voice teacher. Among her notable pupils was opera singer Shirley Verrett. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anna_Fitziu

FWIW, boxes at left have printing: *** Jones Speedometer, New Rochelle, NY books.google.com/books?id=u9FMAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA43&lp... has an article from Machinery, Volume 20, Sept. 1913, with pictures of equipment used to manufacture the speedometers. The emblem on the sleeve indicates that these women were in the U.S. Navy.

See www.archives.gov/publications/prologue/2006/fall/yeoman-f... "On March 19, 1917, the Bureau of Navigation sent letters to the commanders of the naval districts informing them they could recruit women into the Naval Coast Defense Reserve to be "utilized as radio operators, stenographers, nurses, messengers, chauffeurs, etc. and in many other capacities in the industrial line." The new enlisted women were able to become yeomen, electricians (radio operators), or any other ratings necessary to the naval district operations. The majority became yeomen and were designated as yeomen (F) for female yeomen."

Calendar is showing the month of March 1918 and appears to be printed by Baker Printing, Newark, NJ. See "Newark, the City of Industry: Facts and Figures Concerning the Metropolis of Newark, New Jersey," published in 1912, books.google.com/books?id=l1goAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA178&d... for a piece on Baker Printing. This suggests that the pictures of the Navy "yeowomen" were taken in the northeastern U.S.

Note the man oiling the machinery; the 'Oiler', his job was to keep all machinery lubricated.

Some boxes here appear to be labeled "International Arms and Fuse Co., Bloomfield, NJ." Women worked at that plant in 1918, according to "The World of Ruth Draper: A Portrait of an Actress" by Dorothy Warren. books.google.com/books?id=7gy0bsbQ0JkC&pg=PA33&dq...

Other possible locations/companies are: * American Ammunition Company, 25 Broad Street, New York, which built a factory in Paulsboro, NJ in 1917. * American Ordnance Company, Bridgeport, CT * Derby, CT, home of the Driggs-Seabury Gun and Ammunition Company * Driggs-Seabury Ordnance Corporation, with a plant in Sharon, PA, and which also owned the Savage Arms Co. which had a plant in Utica, NY * Linderman Steel and Machine, Co, with plants in Muskegon, Michigan and Woodstock, Ontario. Apparently both plants were involved in the manufacture of naval ordnance in 1918 (according to Moody's Manual, linked below) See, for example, Poor's Manual of Industrials, Volume 7, 1916 books.google.com/books?id=LzxJAQAAMAAJ and Moody's Manual of Railroads and Corporation Securities, 1918 books.google.com/books?id=hmk3AQAAMAAJ

Marguerite Sylva (also known as Marguerita Sylva) (10 July 1875 – 21 February 1957) was a Belgian born mezzo-soprano who achieved fame not only on the opera stage but also in operetta and musical theatre. She was particularly known for her performances in the title role of Bizet's Carmen, which she sang over 300 times in the course of her career. Sylva was a pioneering recording artist for Edison Records and made many recordings for the company between 1910 and 1912. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marguerite_Sylva

Harvard Alumni Bulletin of Oct 6, 1921 books.google.com/books?id=RJEBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA25&lp... indicates that H.N. McCracken was President of Vassar at that point. Notice different spelling. The consensus seems to go for "Mac" rather than "Mc."

S. also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Noble_MacCracken He was president of Vassar College from 1915 to 1946. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McCracken_%28surname%29 states that "Henry Noble McCracken (1880-1970)" (sic) was Chancellor of New York University, but this is apparently mistaken. According to www.nyu.edu/library/bobst/research/arch/chanc.htm, Henry Mitchell MacCracken (his father, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_MacCracken) was chancellor of this institution from 1891 until 1910. (John Henry MacCracken (his brother, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Henry_MacCracken), was acting chancellor in 1910 and 1911.) Henry Noble MacCracken was national director of the Junior Red Cross as well, s. The sun., March 04, 1918, Page 3, col. 6 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1918-03-04/ed-...

New-York tribune., February 18, 1918, Page 9, Col. 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-02-18/ed-... reported that three Presbyterian churches in New York City, including the First Presbyterian, where Duffield was minister, were to combine. Norwich bulletin., April 15, 1918, Page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014086/1918-04-15/ed-... reports that New York Governor Charles Whitman had ordered a court martial for Colonel Asa Bird Gardner who criticized Duffield for wearing his uniform at a dinner. Duffield was chaplain of the Ninth Coast Artillery Regiment of the New York state guard. Whitman had recently ordered state guardsmen to wear their uniforms on all occasions. New-York tribune., May 08, 1918, Page 6, middle of column 5. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-05-08/ed-... reported that the three pastors of the combining Presbyterian congregations were resigning to "make place for some younger man."
