Hiram "Harry" Hendrick Duryea was a brother of Chester Burnell Duryea, the husband of Nina Larrey Smith Duryea www.geni.com/people/Hiram-Duryea/6000000036555181588 I suppose the two women were mixed up by the Bain News Service.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] Interestingly, these Duryeas were heirs to General Hiram Duryea's National Cornstarch Company, which registered the still-existing brand name "Maizena". This General Duryea led the New York 5th Infantry Regiment, "Duryea's Zouaves", in the Civil War and later became president of the family company, making millions. He was shot in 1914 by his son, Chester Burnell Duryea, who went insane: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F0DE3DD173AE633A... Chester was the husband of the lady in the picture, as you say, but they had been divorced in 1902 on charges of cruelty: news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19400110&i... Later on, Hiram "Harry" Hendrick Duryea, Chester's brother commited suicide in 1921: archives.chicagotribune.com/1921/07/28/page/6/article/son...

In another variation, "Mrs. Harry H. Duryea" is identified as chairman of the Entertainment Committee for the March, 1918 Red Cross "Garden Theatre" at the International Flower Show, Grand Central Palace, New York. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-03-01/ed-...

Lieutenant Joseph Charles Stehlin (1897-1967) on an air tour selling liberty bonds. He is wearing a French WWI aviator uniform so he must have been in the Lafayette Escadrille. New York Times on April 14, 1918: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton/25075820414] "If the weather is favorable, Lieutenant Joseph C. Stehlin will start at 3 o'clock o clock this afternoon from Sheepshead Bay on his air flight through New York state in the interest of Liberty Bonds." He was born on 29 January 1897 in Brooklyn, New York City. He died in Miami Florida in 1967. Here is an image from a French archive: [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton/25076003354] gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b53052449n Because he was not in the US military he would need a passport to return to the United states during wartime, so he should have a passport application with the state department ... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Recruit_(1917) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephus_Daniels

Daniels' visit to the Recruit in Union Square was on March 16, 1918: "Daniels Makes Voyage on Good Ship Recruit Secretary Tells Crowd Navy Has Just Begun to Do Things As Josephus Daniels. Secretary of the Navy, climbed aboard the good ship Recruit, anchored in the sea of people that filled Union Square yesterday afternoon, the Secretary's flag, furled for breaking, was loosened to the breeze and the naval band struck up "Hail to the Chief." Advancing bravely toward a battery of motion picture cameras. Mr. Daniels shook hands with Commander Charles A. Adams, in charge of the sturdy vessel. Then followed an informal inspection of the ship no submarine will ever sink. "Why, this is a real ship," remarked the Secretary to her commander. "I can almost hear the waves beating outside." While officers and enlisted men stood at attention, he examined the quarters below, including the aft cabin, resplendent in the gay red furnishings taken from the Vaterland, erstwhile pride of the Kaiser's fleet. Then, followed by his aid, Lieutenant Frost, and Henry McDonnel, director general of the Mayor's committee on National Defence, he climbed to the deck and made a brief address to the crowd. "As this ship stands in the heart of the metropolis," he said. "so our navy is safely anchored in the hearts of the American people. Our boys in blue over there have already captured German submarines, and they have sunk more of them than I can tell." After the cheers which interrupted this comment, he added: "But what they have done is only an inkling of what they will do to bring this war to a successful conclusion." Escorted to the motor car which awaited him near by, the Secretary stood at attention while the band on board played "The Star-Spangled Banner." Before the crowd could surge away another speaker was leaning over the rail, and the good ship Recruit was hitting the stride for which it has become famous. After W. T. Whitmore had finished a brief appeal for volunteers, eleven young men stepped out of the crowd to go to work for Josephus Daniels and Uncle Sam's navy." New York Tribune, March 17, 1918 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-03-17/ed-... This photo, with all hands over hearts and Daniels standing on the running board of his car, is likely the part where the national anthem was played.

Alexander Konstantinovich Glazunov (Russian: Алекса́ндр Константи́нович Глазуно́в, 10 August 1865 – 21 March 1936) was a Russian composer, music teacher, and conductor of the late Russian Romantic period. He served as director of the Saint Petersburg Conservatory between 1905 and 1928 and was also instrumental in the reorganization of the institute into the Petrograd Conservatory, then the Leningrad Conservatory, following the Bolshevik Revolution. He continued heading the Conservatory until 1930, though he had left the Soviet Union in 1928 and did not return. The best known student under his tenure during the early Soviet years was Dmitri Shostakovich. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Glazunov

The reason for the Japanese military being in the news in March 1918 was the situation in Russian Manchuria and Siberia. See, e.g., The [New York] Sun., March 10, 1918, Section 5 Magazine Section, Page 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1918-03-10/ed-... "The President is said to consider that if the American Government accepts responsibility for the entry of Japanese troops into Russian Manchuria and Siberia for purposes of military occupation it also takes upon itself the responsibility for bringing about the withdrawal of the Japanese forces from Muscovite territory when the reason for their presence, namely, the danger of Teuton aggression, has ceased to exist. Now that, it must be admitted, is a heavy burden to shoulder." Also, the New-York Tribune., March 06, 1918, Page 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-03-06/ which has lots of short articles on the war situation in the arenas in and near Russia.

Ishii presented his credentials as Japanese ambassador to President Wilson on April 30, 1918. See Washington Evening Star., May 01, 1918, Page 17 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1918-05-01/ed-...

Henri Farré, (1871-1934) Rough auto-translation of the French Wikipedia article: "Henri Farré (1871-1934) was a painter and aviator in the First World War . Born in Foix 31 July 1871, Son of Michel husband of Marie Monnet, he joined the France while he was in Buenos Aires during mobilization. He became the official painter of the armies on the appointment of General Niox he was as observer driver. He has exhibited his paintings in the United States as a propaganda tool for the Western armies and famous aviators. He had made ​​more than two hundred and fifty works including portraits of the drivers. He was awarded the Legion of Honor and the Croix de Guerre 14-18. 1934 Gold Medal of the Paris Salon for his painting of her four dead son in the war." fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henri_Farr%C3%A9 "EXHIBIT OF WAR PAINTINGS.; Lieut. Farre to Show Official French War Canvases Here. Lieutenant Henri Farre, who has come to America from France at the direction of the French Government as the official representative of the French Air Service at the front, will show while in New York the official paintings he made for the French War Department of combats between the French and allied aircraft and the flying fighting machines of the boches." The show was to be at the Anderson Galleries, 59th St. and Park Avenue, New York from March 10-20, 1918, and was to tour major American cities thereafter. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=940CE5DD113FE4... He died in Chicago on October 6, 1934. His New York Times obituary: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9505EFD8103CE23AB... See also: data.bnf.fr/14794670/henry_farre/

Trying to find more about the couple, I ran into search.archives.jdc.org/multimedia/Documents/NY_AR_45-54/... A 1947 letter on Leterman-Glass letterhead, signed by Mrs. Blanche C. Glass offering some unlabeled packaged food to the "Joint Distribution Committee" for "Europe." A search for "Leterman-Glass" led me to www.beeretseq.com/dora-keogh-irish-pub-and-gary-gillman-t... and the menu for the 2015 event [www.beeretseq.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Beer-Tasting...] which includes pages from the 1944 event, to which Leterman-Glass contributed pretzels. The summary of a 1956 case [ny.findacase.com/research/wfrmDocViewer.aspx/xq/fac.19560...] suggests that Blanche might have later married Leterman.

NYT of Feb 12, 1959, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C02E4DB1E39E632A... announces the death of Mary I. Copeland and names Mrs. Elmer G. Leterman as one of her daughters. Elsewhere in NYT of Feb 12, 1959, query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9407E4DB1E39E632A... confirms that Mary I. Copeland was Mrs. Samuel Copeland and that Mrs. Leterman was Blanche.

Another detail in NYT of October 20, 1950 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E07E5DF123CE333A... "The marriage of Miss Eileen Glass, daughter of Mrs. Blanche Glass of 101 West Fifty-fifth Street, and Herbert Glass of Coral Gables, Fla.,..." suggests that the couple had separated by 1950.

"Roger Ward Babson (July 6, 1875 in Gloucester, Massachusetts – March 5, 1967 in Lake Wales, Florida) was an American entrepreneur, economist and business theorist in the first half of the 20th century. He is best remembered for founding Babson College. He also founded Webber College, now Webber International University, in Babson Park, Florida, and the defunct Utopia College, in Eureka, Kansas." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Babson

Various dates are written on the negative, as far as I can see: 3/9/18, 5/14/18, 9/6/29 The 1929 date is probably associated with Babson's "gloomy predictions" about the stockmarket. NYT of September 06, 1929 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A05E2DD1F30E33AB... "STOCK PRICES BREAK ON DARK PROPHECY; Drop in Hectic Last Hour as Babson's Prediction of a Big Slump Is Printed. ... Out of a clear sky a storm of selling broke on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon and in one hour wiped out millions of dollars in the open market value of securities of all sorts." Among the factors suggested in the article: "The prediction at Wellesley Mass., by Roger Babson that stocks are due for a collapse not unlike the collapse of the Florida boom in real estate." See another article on the same date query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D07E1DD1F30E33AB... for more about the speech.

"COURT HOUSE CRATER EASY FOR BRITISH TANK; Women on Recruiting Mission Go Down into Five Points No Man's Land-Jews Off to War. Under command of Captain Haigh of the British Army and manned by its crew of eight veteran English soldiers, all of whom have seen service at the front, the British Tank Britannia cruised the streets of downtown New York yesterday seeking recruits for the British army." On February 28, 1918, the tank went into and out of an excavation where the old Five Points was, planned for a courthouse. Three women came along, Mrs. Adolph Ladenburg, Mrs. Frederick Pearson Jr., and Miss Ray Slater. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9902E7DA113FE433A...

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] The correct spelling is Adolph or Adolf Ladenburg. The Washington times., February 28, 1918, FINAL EDITION, Page 14 reported that Mrs. Adolf Ladenburg and Miss Ray Slater were guests of a dinner at the St. Regis, New York (col. 4, "Gives Dinner In New York") chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1918-02-28/ed-... S. also comments under www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/25390267712/ and www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/25415972981/
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] Spelling corrected, thanks.

"The most interesting war relic ever seen in America will be used in General White’s great recruiting campaign. This relic is none other than the tank Britannia, which has already been seen in New York and Canada, but is still a decided novelty to people all over the United States. The Britannia is a genuine British tank, and has seen service on the Flanders front. When it first appeared upon the streets of New York, it caused a great sensation us it lumbered along Fifth avenue. and later on was the biggest hit at the Hero Land bazaar. An extensive itinerary has been laid out for the tank and its crew of veterans, several of whom bear wounds received in the service. This novel land battleship carries six machine guns, and is an awe-inspiring sight as it moves over rough country and deep ditches with the same ease and speed it shows when it attacks the German trenches on the French front." Cambridge Sentinel, Volume XV, Number 10, 26 January 1918 cambridge.dlconsulting.com/cgi-bin/cambridge?a=d&d=Se... We have seen Britannia in New York before:

The New York Tribune also reported on this event in its March 1, 1918 edition: "Society Women Enjoy Ride Here In the Big British Tank Britannia War Machine Rumbles Through "No Man's Land" at the Municipal Building in Appeal for Volunteers for England and Canada British tank Britannia functioned yesterday before 3,000 spectators on the courthouse site behind the Municipal Building with three society women aboard. The fierce engine of destruction continued to do the constructive work of getting Britishers and Canadians to enlist. To Mrs. Adolph Ladenburg, Mrs. Frederick Pearson, Jr., and Miss S. Slater the honor of being the first New York women to ride in a tank was reserved. The rough, unlevel condition of the courthouse site gave the women an excellent indication of the sensation combatants experience when in tanks which climb hills and destroy mounds and obstructions as easily as a worm crawls. When the Britannia leaned violently toward front end Mrs. Ladenburg stuck her head out of a door at the top of the tank, and the spectators cheered her valor enthusiastically. When the women dismounted from the strange convenience they seemed none the worse for their experience, although their dresses were badly mussed. " chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1918-03-01/ed-...
Thanks Art Siegel and B-59 for the interesting details about the tank Britannia and its visit to New York City. We will add more information when we update.

David Baird, Sr. (April 7, 1839 – February 25, 1927) was a U.S. Senator from New Jersey. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Baird_(New_Jersey)

from wikipedia: "he was appointed on February 23, 1918 to the Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the death of William Hughes. He was subsequently elected as a Republican on November 5, 1918 and until March 4, 1919, when he did not run for reelection."

Bisbee Daily Review ran this photo on March 14, 1918 with the caption: "David Baird. Governor Edge of New Jersev has appointed David Baird to succeed the late U. S. Senator Hughes. Baird will be only a fill-in senator, announcing that he will not be a candidate to succeed himself next November. The new senator is seventy eight years old." chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024827/1918-03-14/ed-... The 1927 date on the negative is probably for a re-use at his death.

"Field Marshal Henry Maitland Wilson, 1st Baron Wilson GCB, GBE, DSO (5 September 1881 – 31 December 1964), also known as "Jumbo" Wilson, was a senior British Army officer of the 20th century. He saw active service in the Second Boer War and then during the First World War on the Somme and at Passchendaele. During the Second World War he served as General Officer Commanding-in-Chief (GOC-in-C) British Troops in Egypt, in which role he launched Operation Compass, attacking Italian forces with considerable success, in December 1940. He went on to be Military Governor of Cyrenaica in February 1941, commanding a Commonwealth expeditionary force to Greece in April 1941 and General Officer Commanding (GOC) British Forces in Palestine and Trans-Jordan in May 1941. Wilson became GOC Ninth Army in Syria and Palestine in October 1941, GOC Persia and Iraq Command in August 1942 and GOC Middle East Command in February 1943. In the closing stages of the war he was Supreme Allied Commander in the Mediterranean, from January 1944, and then Chief of the British Joint Staff Mission in Washington D. C. from January 1945." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Maitland_Wilson

"Flora Sandes (22 January 1876 – 24 November 1956) was the only British woman officially to serve as a soldier in World War I. She was subsequently promoted to the rank of Sergeant major, and, after the war, to Captain. She was decorated with seven medals." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flora_Sandes

He received a commendation for bravery in February, 1918 for his efforts in trying to prevent the sinking of Coast Guard Steamer McCulloch in June, 1917. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9C0CE1DD113FE4...

His son's 1993 obituary mentions "Glover was born Feb. 11, 1912, in Washington, D.C., the son of Coast Guard Capt. Jesse W. Glover and his wife, Mable, and the great grandson of Gold Rush Californians. His parents settled in Palo Alto, where, during the Depression, they attracted national attention for a homeless shelter they established on the site of the current Holiday Inn." news.stanford.edu/pr/93/931119Arc3037.html Their work during the Depression was also mentioned in Mrs. Glover's 1964 obituary: "SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3—Mrs. Mary Belle Moore Glover, who had been active in relief work for the unemployed and with the Red Cross, died here today. She was 89 years old. With her husband, the late Capt. Jesse W. Glover, a retired Coast Guard officer, she estab-lished a chain of northern Cali-fornia shelters for the jobless during the Depression. She di-rected the San Francisco shel-ter." www.nytimes.com/1964/11/04/mrs-jesse-w-glover.html?_r=0 That work was summarized in this article, which contains later photos of Capt. Glover: www.paloaltohistory.org/hotel-de-zink.php The San Francisco Chronicle for April 21, 1957 ran a story on the Glovers' 50th wedding anniversary, mentioning that he had been, during WWII, "West Coast housing and feeding director for the Japanese Evacuation Camps." According to a Chronicle obituary, he died of a heart attack, on July 19th, 1960, at the age of 80, while waiting for a bus at Second and Market Streets in San Francisco. Interesting that his heroism in the McCulluch sinking seemed to drop out of later accounts of his life.

"Sally Hamlin (born Sarah Emery Hamlin, Dec. 23 1902, Brooklyn, New York, USA, died July 4, 1987, Bar Harbor, Maine) was a child actor and recording artist. She is a shadowy figure today, and would probably be completely forgotten were it not for a series of 78rpm spoken word recordings she made for children in the 1910s and 1920s. Sally recorded primarily for Victor, but also recorded a few 7" discs for Emerson Records. These records were readings of poetry by such authors as Eugene Field and James Whitcomb Riley, classic stories such as Cinderella and Rumpelstilskin, and even excerpts from Pollyanna by Eleanor H. Porter." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sally_Hamlin Listen here: archive.org/details/SallyHamlin

This must be the Princeton Airport which is still on Rt 206 about four miles north of town. I myself learned to fly at this airport, although it was a summer adventure of ten lessons leading to solo. I didn't continue it after that (busy with school). My dad, a private pilot of many years standing, was anxious for me to do it. A fun and rewarding challenge! In my day, 1957, it was still a grass landing strip. I learned in the Princeton University's Aeronca, an antique by then, but not quite a Jenny!

The December 28, 1917 Brooklyn Eagle ran 3 pictures in this series with the caption. "Training American war eagles to fly- at the Princeton Aviation School. The college men training to become aviators are here shown assembling a motor for an airplane. The aviators have to be expert in motor construction. Frank Stanton, flying instructor of Princeton, who is teaching the art of flying to Princeton men. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_Thompson_Seton "Ernest Thompson Seton (August 14, 1860 – October 23, 1946) was an author (published in the United Kingdom, Canada, and the US), wildlife artist, founder of the Woodcraft Indians, and one of the founding pioneers of the Boy Scouts of America (BSA)."
swanq: Thanks for locating more information on Seton. We will update the record.

Seton was involved in a wartime movement to raise and eat potatoes, of which the poster he is shown holding was a part. He did this through his Woodcraft League of America, forming Woodcraft Potato Clubs. idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=TUC1... The May, 1918 number of The Guide To Nature ran the following article about Seton's activities: "Potatriotism is Potato Patriotism The War and You is an interesting announcement of The Woodcraft League of America Incorporation to the Woodcraft Potato Clubs. The Woodcrafters this coming summer are to devote their energies to raising potatoes under the skilled direction of the chief Mr Ernest Thompson Seton, whose home is in Greenwich Connecticut. Every one should be interested in these potato clubs and we advise all our readers to send to The Woodcraft League of America at 13 West Twenty ninth Street New York City for full particulars There is a catchy bit of inspiration in the appeal of this league to be a potato patriot and their slogan "Let's hoe our way to victory ." There is a Thompson cartoon like the one in the picture above, showing a cartoon animal reading this poem: "Some call em murphies, some call em goods Some call em taties, some call em spuds Some call em tubers, or hoe-fruit clean, But our jolly little Hoe boys call em National Steam! Copyright Ernest Thompson Seton, Chief of the Woodcraft League of America" books.google.com/books?id=uNIeAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA357&d... see also

The Cambridge, Mass. Sentinel ran this story on May 18, 1918: "Home gardeners last year were prompted by only one patriotic impulse, to help increase our food supply. This year there is a second reason, the need to do all that we can to avoid further congestion of freight shipments. On account of their bulk in shipment, potatoes are therefore one of the most important of the vegetables for home growing and because of this the work of the Woodcraft Potato clubs, founded last year by Ernest Thompson Seton, is meeting a hearty response. These clubs of boy and girl ‘potatriots” as Mr. Seton has dubbed them, flourished in 26 states last year and the indications are that their number will much more than double this spring. Their slogan Is “Grow a bushel of potatoes and save a bushel of transportation.” cambridge.dlconsulting.com/cgi-bin/cambridge?a=d&d=Se...

Similar shot, captioned "Stanton, one of America's most famous airmen, with the two mascots of the Princeton Aviation School", from a 1919 publication. archive.org/stream/warillustratedal09hammuoft#page/3122/m...

Hector Dufranne (25 October 1870 – 4 May 1951) was a Belgian operatic bass-baritone who enjoyed a long career that took him to opera houses throughout Europe and the United States for more than four decades. Admired for both his singing and his acting, Dufranne appeared in a large number of world premieres, most notably the role Golaud in the original production of Claude Debussy's Pelléas et Mélisande in 1902, which he went on to sing 120 times at that house.[1] He had an excellent singing technique which maintained the quality of his voice even into the latter part of his career. His wide vocal range and rich resonant voice enabled him to sing a variety of roles which encompassed French, German, and Italian opera. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hector_Dufranne

They were both to sing in Thais and Le Sauteriot. Dalmores was also to perform in Carmen.

A little more on this, from the April, 1918 issue of The Recruit: "One of the outstanding features of the recent campaign to insure the lives the men in the service was the War Insurance Calendar, the origin of Frances Jordan 226 West 70th Street New York City. Approximately 300,000 copies of the calendar were distributed in the many camps of the country. Miss Jordan's photograph was selected as the most attractive and most suitable for the purpose of the calendar from hundreds submitted by girls throughout the country. Only girls with relatives or close friends in the service were eligible to submit them and this placed the nation wide search for "the prettiest girl in America" on a patriotic plane. A board of artists headed by Director Felix Mahoney of the School of Fine and Applied Arts made the awards. Miss Jordan has a brother SapperJohn F Jordan at Camp Spartanburg SC and an uncle Horace Gillmore No 913703 Canadian Engineers 6th Field Company in France." books.google.com/books?id=N_YHrdnas10C&pg=PA65&lp...

She wed a few years later: "BEAUTY PRIZE WINNER WEDS; Miss Frances Jordan Marries Lieut. Commander Frank Huntoon. Miss Frances Jordan of 468 Riverside Drive, who was adjudged by a committee of artists in Washington the prettiest girl among 22,000 whose photographs were submitted in a competition for a picture with which to decorate the calendar of the War Risk Insurance Bureau, was married yesterday afternoon.. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B00E5D81638E1...

"Elihu Root (/ˈɛlᵻhjuː ˈruːt/; February 15, 1845 – February 7, 1937) was an American lawyer and statesman who served as the Secretary of War (1899–1904) under two presidents, including President Theodore Roosevelt. He was the prototype of the 20th century revolving door, shuttled between high-level appointed government positions in Washington, D.C. and private-sector legal practice in New York City. He was elected by the state legislature as a US Senator from New York and served one term, 1909–1915. Root was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1912." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elihu_Root Elsewhere on Flickr Commons (DC Public Library):

"Paul Ludwig Hans Anton von Beneckendorff und von Hindenburg (About this sound listen (help·info)), known universally as Paul von Hindenburg (German: [ˈpaʊl fɔn ˈhɪndn̩bʊɐ̯k] ( listen); 2 October 1847 – 2 August 1934) was a German military officer, statesman, and politician who served as the second President of Germany during the period 1925-1934. Hindenburg retired from the army for the first time in 1911, but was recalled shortly after the outbreak of World War I in 1914. He first came to national attention at the age of 66 as the victor of the decisive Battle of Tannenberg in August 1914. As Germany's Chief of the General Staff from August 1916, Hindenburg's reputation rose greatly in German public esteem. He and his deputy Erich Ludendorff would then lead Germany in a de facto military dictatorship throughout the remainder of the war, marginalizing German Emperor Wilhelm II as well as the German Reichstag. In line with Lebensraum ideology, he advocated sweeping annexations of territory in Poland, Ukraine and Russia in order to re-settle Germans there." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_von_Hindenburg see

"Mark Requa (1866-1937) - Mining Magnate; Confidant to President Hoover Mark Requa was a leader of the Republican Party and one of President Herbert Hoover’s most trusted advisors. He directed Hoover’s presidential campaign in California in 1928 and for the entire West in 1932. At the Republican Convention in 1928, it was Requa who placed the name of his fellow engineer into nomination for President. The two men became close friends while attending engineering classes at Stanford University. In his professional life, Requa was a successful mining magnate, founding the Nevada Consolidated Copper Company, owning gold and silver mines, and serving as vice president of the American Institute of Mining and Metalurgical Engineers. He also played a major role in building the Nevada Northern Railway, which transported his metals to the Pacific coast for shipping. Requa was born on Christmas Day in 1866 and was educated in private schools. In 1895 he married the former Florence Herrick of Oakland, with whom he had three children. Requa died from complications following an operation. Upon his death, Herbert Hoover proclaimed: “Mark Requa was one of the most honest, the most loyal, the most idealistic men that California has produced.” mountainviewpeople.blogspot.com/2009/11/requa-long-mining...
www.loc.gov/item/hec2009005493/ is an LoC portrait of Requa from another collection.

"Valentine Everitt Macy (1871–1930) was an American industrialist and philanthropist, involved in local government. He served as the commissioner of the Westchester County, New York Department of Charities and Corrections from 1913–1919, as Commissioner of Public Welfare in 1925, and as Commissioner of Parks from 1926-1930. BARONESS ZOLLNER HELD ON SPY CHARGE; Lieut. Spaulding, U.S.A., Arrested With Her at Hotel, Sentto Fort Oglethorpe. CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 24.-- Baroness Iona Zollner of New York, wife of a German army officer serving on the Flanders front, was held without bail for the Federal Grand Jury here today on the charge of violating ... December 25, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9404E0DC1E3BE03AB...

The NYT article Richard Norton links to indicates that she had a 16-year-old son, Bedford Shope, presumably this young man. It looks as though she also had an older son -- or names/initials were confused. The Arkansas City Daily Traveler, February 28, 1918, Page 8 www.newspapers.com/newspage/53693708/ reports that "Midshipman William K. B. Shope, son of Baroness Zollner" had withdrawn from the Naval Academy at Annapolis.

The Harding Affair: Love and Espionage during the Great War by James David Robenalt has a note on page 396 that suggests there were two sons, Bedford and Beresford. books.google.com/books?id=MX-jH6hW80YC&pg=PA373&l...; Bedford Shope clearly gave testimony at her trial according to notes in the same book (only partially visible through Google books). American Legion Magazine, Volume 8, No. 3 (March 1930) archive.legion.org/handle/123456789/3317?show=full includes a piece called Drums & Bugles by Beresford Shope that places him as the son at the Naval Academy and in which he says, "eventually, I got a commission." He transferred to the Army. I haven't tracked Bedford down later in life.

Her death announcement in the NYT of March 12, 1932 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B05E6DC1F3FE633A... does not mention her marriage to Zollner. She died in Paris and was going by "Mrs. Iona Wilhelmina Sutton-Shope." No mention of her sons.

Frederick Albert Wallis (March 13, 1869 - December 21, 1951) was the fourth Deputy Police Commissioner of New York City. He was the U.S. Commissioner of Immigration, a NYC Department of Corrections Commissioner, and a Democratic National Convention delegate query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=950CEED81E3CEE3AB... www.correctionhistory.org/html/chronicl/nycdoc/html/walli... id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n90642709.html

The NYT article from April 30, 1920 linked by  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/richard_arthur_norton] above indicates that Mr. Wallis had been appointed Fourth Deputy Police Commissioner of New York in January 1918.
Richard Norton and swanq: Thanks!  We will include your more complete information for Wallis next time we up these descriptions.

Apparently the various Deputy Commissioners had specialized roles: "By virtue of custom, the Fourth Deputy Commissioner is the business man of the Police Administration, and on him rests the responsibility of administering the financial affairs of the Police Department. Fourth Deputy Commissioner F.A. Wallis was chosen for the post largely because of his established reputation as an energetic and successful business man and his vast experience in managing big enterprises. He at once eliminated all unnecessary offices and wasteful practices in the bureaus under his supervision. Under his charge are: Chief Clerk's Office Issuance of all permits and licenses issued by the Department, Bureau of Repairs and Supplies Printing Bureau, Pension Investigations, Methods of making and keeping records and reports. Certifies and signs bills and pay-rolls of the Department, Conduct of trials as specially assigned by the Police Commissioner. " Annual report / Police Department, City of New York, 1918 archive.org/stream/annual18newy#page/n87/mode/2up
Apparently related to Polish Falcons recruiting efforts during WWI. See
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/24207582543/in/photostream/]
and

This set of 3 pictures seems to have to do with the recruiting activities of the Polish Falcons, based in Pittsburgh, PA, to recruit American Poles into part of the Polish Army: "To expedite recruiting the MilitaryCommission divided the recruiting areas into twelve centers, each headed by commissioned military personnel. To Pittsburgh's recruiting officer Dr. B. M. Zielinski, a noted patriot and orator, was assigned Number 1 and the recruiting center became known as "Centrum 6." Being energetic and zealous Dr. Zielinski lost no time in organizing the scattered Polish colonies into one smooth functioning recruiting unit." The Polish Falcons still exist. This from their website: "The vision of a resurrected, free Poland was close to the hearts of the early Falcon organization, which became a leader among Polish American groups in working toward this goal. By 1917, over 25,000 young Polish American men were trained by the Polish Falcons to serve in a proposed Polish military force. During World War I, these Falcon-trained troops became the core of the Polish-American expeditionary force in France and the eventual nucleus of the Polish Army. At the Polish Falcons Convention held in Pittsburgh on April 3, 1917, the renowned pianist and future premier of newly independent Poland, Ignacy Paderewski, delivered a rousing speech that sparked the recruitment of a Polish Army in the United States to fight for the Western Allies against Germany. Over 35,000 Polish-American men enlisted in the Allied war effort. In particular, these Falcon trained troops fought in the famous “Blue Army” under the leadership of General Jozef Haller. When Poland regained its independence in 1918, these troops helped to form the nucleus of the young country’s armed forces as neighboring countries immediately attacked Poland, including the fierce Bolshevik Red Army that was planning on spreading communism into Europe by invading Poland." www.polishfalcons.org/History

Herbert Clark Hoover (August 10, 1874 – October 20, 1964) was the 31st President of the United States
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Hoover Dates written on negative are 6/16/28 and 12/11/20 or 28. However, that doesn't mean that the photo wasn't taken in 1917/18.

Chattanooga news., February 13, 1918, LATE EDITION, Image 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038531/1918-02-13/ed-... shows a full page ad. with Hoover pointing a finger at the reader, "Food will win the war." He was Director of the U.S. Food Administration.

The 6/16/28 date relates to Hoover's nomination as Republican candidate for President. In December 1920, he was involved with activities to support American exports and a European Relief Council. He was in New York on 12/19/20, according to NYT of 12/20/1920 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A06E0DB173CE533A... to raise money for the European Relief Council.
Thanks Richard Norton and swanq for the information about Herbert Hoover Director of the U.S. Food Administration and future president. We will add more details when we update.

A scrawl at the bottom of this negative is ?/24/18, possibly 9/24/18. At that time Hoover was Chairman of the Committee for the Relief of Belgium. See NYT of 9/24/18 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9905E2D81531E433A...

Hoover did come to New York in March 1918, on 3/10. See NYT of March 11, 1918 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D0DE2D61538EE32A... He came to New York for a conference with the "local Milling Division." Evening star., March 12, 1918, Page 9, top right. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1918-03-12/ed-... reported: "NEW YORK. March 12. Fifty-seven restaurants and lunchrooms whose proprietors have confessed to ignoring food regulation were closed today by order of local food administrators with the approval of Herbert Hoover, the national administrator. The places will remain closed until midnight tonight. Mr. Hoover, who attended a conference here yesterday with local officials issued a warning that extreme penalties would follow further violations of the food conservation rules. One hundred East Side bakers, who are alleged not to be making victory bread exclusively, have been warned that unless they comply with the regulations their flour supply will be be cut off." But none of this pins down when and where this photo was taken.

Joseph-Marie–Auguste Caillaux (French pronunciation: ​[ʒɔzɛf kajo]; 30 March 1863 Le Mans – 22 November 1944 Mamers) was a French politician of the Third Republic. He was a leader of the French Radical party and minister of finance, but his progressive views in opposition to the military alienated him from conservative elements. He was accused of corruption, but was cleared by a parliamentary commission. This political weakness strengthened the right wing elements in the radical party. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Caillaux
This photo of Caillaux, then facing treason charges in France, was published in the December 29, 1917 issue of The Literary Review. www.unz.org/Pub/LiteraryDigest-1917dec29-00023

William Abram Mann (July 31, 1854 – October 8, 1934) was a general officer in the United States Army. He served as the commander of the 17th Infantry Brigade in the Spanish–American War of 1898 and the commander of the 42nd Infantry Division ("The Rainbow Division") in World War I. After he retired from military service, he became an executive at Equitable Trust Company of New York. He resided in Washington D.C., until his death on October 8, 1934. He had a troop carrier (AP-112) named after him, that was commissioned in 1943 and served in World War II, the Korean War, and the Vietnam War. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Abram_Mann John Breitling Coulter (1891–1983) was a Lieutenant General in the United States Army. Coulter served during World Wars I and II and the Korean War. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_B._Coulter

A cropped version of this photo ran in the Duluth (Minn) Herald for February 5, 1918 with the caption: "COLLEEN FIRST APPLICANT AT WOMEN'S WAR BUREAU The first applicant for employment at the Federal bureau for the employment of women was a pretty colleen from Kilkenny - Emily Murphy. She is 18 years old and has been 10 months in the United States. Her brother is with the colors." fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?uri=http%... "Women in Industry Service United States 1918 Synopsis During spring 1917 the United States began shipping thousands of men overseas to fight in World War I. This immediate strain on the U.S. labor force created problems for industry, which became overburdened by wartime production requirements. The War Labor Administration, a division of the U.S. Department of Labor, worked to resolve these problems in part by replacing male workers with female ones. Realizing that women's labor issues needed to be addressed specifically, as well as to prevent them from disrupting wartime production, the Department of Labor created the Women in Industry Service (WIS) in 1918. This cooperative-based bureau was run by women for women. Most of its policy suggestions for addressing women's labor issues were later implemented. Although the end of the war in November 1918 meant the return of men to industry, the WIS succeeded in bringing governmental attention to the rights of women laborers. The WIS operated until 1920, when Congress granted the bureau permanent status through public law; the organization then became known as the U.S. Women's Bureau. As the only federal organization devoted to the welfare of working women, the Women's Bureau became a powerful advocate for their rights, conducting industry research and helping to shape public policy regarding their welfare." www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-3408900320/women-industr...

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baalbek "In Greek and Roman antiquity, it was known as Heliopolis. ... Heliopolis is the latinisation of the Greek Hēlioúpolis (Ἡλιούπολις), meaning "Sun City" in reference to the solar cult there. This particular feature may have seen considerable deterioration since the Bain photo was taken. See my photos from 2011: I believe the second photo shows the corner of the decorative wall (of a pool) where the children are sitting. I could be wrong about which apse is pictured here and thus about the deterioration. I remember that there are apses on the north side of the Great Court too and there may be similar pools. The picture sankablog.files.wordpress.com/2008/11/im002642.jpg (see blog post at sankablog.wordpress.com/2008/11/24/beirut-baalbek-and-back/) suggests that a matching apse on the other side has had some restoration including some columns added (back?).

I think the children are NOT sitting on the edge of the southern basin, as it's visible here www.flickr.com/photos/troels/3497581228/ but on the northern basin with the north portico in the background: www.flickr.com/photos/antoine-appr/16094001756/ The columns were obviously rebuilt. The whole scene is visible here: www.flickr.com/photos/fatima81/22780029936/ or in better quality: upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e8/Pano_Baalbek_... A plan of the temple complex is here: de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tempel_von_Baalbek#/media/File:Burg...

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] -- I'm sure you are right.  The reconstructed columns and the sheer scale of the site meant that I didn't recognize the original symmetry of the Great Court's apses.
www.panoramio.com/photo/9002634 is a good closeup of the exedra on the north side, with the rebuilt columns. Like the Bain photo, it shows the remains of a statue in the lower left niche.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baalbek The Library of Congress has another collection with lots of photographs of Baalbek. See www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/matpc/ "The majority of the images depict Palestine (present day Israel and the West Bank) from 1898 to 1946. Most of the collection consists of over 22,000 glass and film photographic negatives and transparencies created by the American Colony Photo Department and its successor firm, the Matson Photo Service." A search for Baalbek -- www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=baalbek&co=matpc&s... -- finds 243 photos. Over the years, with more research, names assigned to the different structures of the enormous, fantastic site have changed. The name "Temple of the Sun" is no longer used. The six columns in the foreground are part of the Temple of Jupiter and the more complete temple behind the columns is now known as the Temple of Bacchus. www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/matpc.00226 is a photo in the opposite direction

A stereograph of the same view is at www.rubylane.com/item/131167-RL1230-B78A/Early-Baalbek-Le... The Yale expositor., December 26, 1918 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn98066406/1918-12-26/ed-... had a piece on the site, linking it loosely to the British expedition in Palestine. Richmond times-dispatch., November 17, 1918 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045389/1918-11-17/ed-... has the headline, "The Home of the Cruel God Baal is Now in Christian Hands."

The Halifax Explosion was a maritime disaster in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada, on the morning of 6 December 1917. SS Mont-Blanc, a French cargo ship laden with high explosives, collided with the Norwegian vessel SS Imo in the Narrows, a strait connecting the upper Halifax Harbour to Bedford Basin. A fire on board the French ship ignited her cargo, causing a large explosion that devastated the Richmond district of Halifax. Approximately 2,000 people were killed by debris, fires and collapsed buildings, and an estimated 9,000 others were injured.[1] From: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halifax_Explosion

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_W._Bagley "David Worth Bagley (January 8, 1883 – May 24, 1960) was an admiral in the United States Navy during World War II. ... On December 6, 1917, Bagley conned his ship out of Brest harbor. At about 1621 that afternoon, the watch spied a torpedo wake. The destroyer maneuvered to avoid the torpedo, but in vain. It struck her starboard side and pierced her fuel oil tank. Though Bagley and his crew worked frantically to save the ship, she went down within eight minutes carrying 64 crewmen with her. Bagley and 37 others made it into the icy water in boats and on rafts, and, thanks to the humanitarian gesture by Kapitänleutnant Hans Rose, the U-boat commander who radioed their location to Queenstown, they were all picked up by the 8th. Bagley earned the Navy Distinguished Service Medal for his part in handling the situation."

The Office (Westfir) Bridge "The Office Covered Bridge was built in 1944 by the Westfir Lumber Company and spans the North Fork of the Middle Fork of the Willamette River, once the site of a mill pond at the town of Westfir. "The wooden span was constructed for logging trucks and connected a lumber mill and its office; hence its name. "The Office Bridge is Oregon’s longest covered span at 180 feet. "The company-owned town, including the bridge, were sold to an investment company in 1977. In the early 1980s the mill burned and the bridge was closed to traffic. "In 1992 the bridge became the property of Lane County through tax foreclosure. Extensive repair work in 1992 stabilized the bridge condition, and in 2002, a new roof was added. "A distinctive feature of the span is the covered walkway separate from the roadway. Because the bridge was built for carrying loaded log trucks, the truss members are gigantic with multiple tension rods and compound chord members. The house has horizontal shiplap siding." – The Covered Bridge Society of Oregon

"As one approached Boston Terminal (South Station) from the South on the former Old Colony Mainline, all inbound and outbound trains had to cross one of the 3 Rolling Lift Bridges that spanned the South Bay Channel. These bridges, which took 2 years to build carried untold amount of passengers & trains during their 87 year lifetime. "The driving force to build Boston Terminal (South Station's Real Name) back in 1894 required the co-operation & consolidation of 4 Railroads: The New England Railroad (NY&NE), The Boston & Providence Railroad (B&P), the Old Colony Railroad (OCRR), and the Boston & Albany Railroad (B&A) to all share 1 common railroad terminal instead of being spread out all over Boston. In order to do this, the planners needed to accommodate the approach tracks for these 4 railroads & funnel them all into the South Station yards & platforms." Read more about this bridge in this fascinating blog, The Rolling Lift Bridge by John Sheridan. The Library of Congress has a collection of 47 amazing photographs of the Fort Point Channel Rolling Lift Bridge in their collection, including several detail views that no ordinary person would ever have the chance to see in person. Tower bridges – Then and Now (100+ Years Later) "Tower bridges" 1904 by Detroit Publishing Company "Old Colony Railroad Bridge" 2010 by Penny Camberville "When the bridges were torn-down in the 1980s, plans were created to preserve the memory of the bridges that kept traffic moving for over 85 years. If you are coming to South Station on any of the Old Colony tracks, look to the right as the train is crossing the remains of Fort Point Channel. There you will see, painted bright red is a piece of the original bridge - still watching passengers cross the channel." – John Sheridan, "The Rolling Lift Bridge"

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Zeppelins has a list of Zeppelins and identifies those that landed or were brought down in England. Candidates wrecked before late 1917 are L48. But the CPI picture doesn’t match the location shown in www.nzhistory.net.nz/media/photo/zeppelin-wreck, with a picture of the June 16/17, 1917 wreck of L48. SL11 crashed at Cuffley, Hertfordshire,. Night of 2/3 September 1916 — first success in bringing a Zeppelin down. L31 -- crashed and landed on an oak tree, near Potters Bar. 2 October 1916. There is no oak tree in this picture. L32 was brought down on September 24, 1916 near Snail’s Farm, South Green, Great Burstead, Essex. Came down in flames. This seems to show the shape of the craft more than one burned would do. See twitter.com/adie1412/status/569584798643183617 for a photo that purports to be of L32. L33 landed in Little Wigborough, Essex, near New Hall Farm. September 24, 1916. Crew attempted to burn the craft, but unsuccessfully. www.google.com/maps/place/New+Hall+Bungalow,+Copt+Hall+Ln... is certainly similar terrain and descriptions suggest that it was in two fields. See www.tollesburyazaz.fsnet.co.uk/News/March02/Wigborough.htm. Strongest candidate, I believe. For more, see: www.essex.police.uk/museum/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/7.pdf article on “Somewhere over Essex: The Zeppelin Raids on Essex.” www.historyhouse.co.uk/articles/zeppelins.html blackmorehistory.blogspot.com/2008/08/zeppelins-over-esse...

Admiral of the Fleet Rosslyn Erskine Wemyss, 1st Baron Wester Wemyss, GCB, CMG, MVO (12 April 1864 – 24 May 1933), known as Sir Rosslyn Wemyss between 1916 and 1919, was a Royal Navy officer. During the First World War he served as commander of the 12th Cruiser Squadron and then as Governor of Moudros before leading the British landings at Cape Helles and at Suvla Bay during the Gallipoli Campaign. He went on to be Commander of the East Indies & Egyptian Squadron in January 1916 and then First Sea Lord in December 1917, in which role he encouraged Admiral Roger Keyes, Commander of the Dover Patrol, to undertake more vigorous operations in the Channel, ultimately leading to the launch of the Zeebrugge Raid in April 1918. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosslyn_Wemyss,_1st_Baron_Wester_We...

James Edgar Gregg (1875-1946) viaf.org/viaf/131768079 www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=104526349 New Head For Hampton. The Rev. James E. Gregg Appointed Principal of Institute. The Trustees of Hampton Institute announced yesterday that the Rev. James E. Gregg of Pittsfield, Mass., had been appointed principal of the school in succession to the late Dr. H.B. Frissell. (December 24, 1917 in New York Times) query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9504E2DC1E3BE0... I added him to Wikidata: www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q21995632 Biography: James Edgar Gregg. Born at Hartford, Conn., Nov. 24, 1875. Son of James Bartlett and Mary (Needham) Gregg. School: Cutler Academy, Colorado Springs, Col. Years In College: 1893-97. A.B.; A.M. 1901; B.D. 1903 (Yale). Married: Pauline Pumpelly, March 16, 1903, Middletown, R.I., died May 27, 1911; Mary Livingston Hinsdale, Pittsfield, Mass., June 10, 1914. Children: Elise Pumpelly, April 3, 1908; James, Sept. 1, 1909; Theodore Hinsdale, April 17, 1915; Gerald Hinsdale, Sept. 3, 1916. Occupation: School principal. Address: Hampton Institute, Hampton, Va. In the autumn of 1897 I went to Newport, R.I., where I served as an instructor in St. George's School for three years. I then returned to Cambridge to study theology in the Harvard Divinity School for one year, at the close of which I received a Master's degree. I took two more years of theology at Yale, receiving there the degree of Bachelor of Divinity in 1903. My first parish was that of the Pilgrim Memorial Church in Pittsfield, Mass., where I was from July, 1903, till October, 1909. From October, 1909, till March, 1912, I was minister of Kirk Street Church, Lowell, Mass.; returning thence to Pittsfield to become minister of the First Church of Christ (Congregational), of which my earlier Pittsfield charge was an outgrowth. It was pleasant for many reasons to renew former associations in the Berkshires; and I had six years of profitable and happy experience with the old First Church, until in April, 1918, I came to Hampton Institute to serve as its principal, in succession to the late Dr. Hollis Burke Frissell. It has been a great privilege to be admitted to the circle of his friends, both in the North and in the South; and the enterprise of promoting the true " education for life" of Negro and Indian youth, as carried on according to the principles of General Samuel Chapman Armstrong and Dr. Booker T. Washington, becomes more and more interesting as an adventure, and more sobering as a responsibility, the deeper one gets into it. I was abroad for a few weeks in the autumn of 1911, visiting England and Scotland; where, in company with a boy, I had traveled in the summer of 1899. I am sorry that I have no war record to relate to my grandchildren, and that my printed compositions are so few as scarcely to be worth listing. An article entitled "Pedagogy and Atonement" in the Biblical Review, published at the University of Chicago, in the issue of April, 1915 (?), and an occasional short article on some aspect of the Negro question practically comprise my output. I trust that any members of the class who may visit Norfolk or Old Point Comfort will not fail to look me up and let me show them the work of the Institute and the other points of interest, such as Langley Field and the Newport News Shipyard in this neighborhood. Hampton is said to be the oldest continuously inhabited settlement of English-speaking people on the North American continent. Yorktown and Williamsburg are within easy motoring distance; and we expect before long to have a good road all the way from Richmond to the end of the Peninsula. Publications: "Atonement," in the Biblical Review, April, 1915. Published at University of Chicago. An occasional short article on some aspect of the Negro question. (Source: Harvard College, 1922)

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_R._Peat "Harold Reginald Peat (July 12, 1893 – 1960) was a Canadian soldier and author. Born in Jamaica, and emigrated to Toronto with his mother, Peat was educated privately and at boarding school in Kingston, Jamaica. He served as a private in the 3rd Battalion of the First Canadian Contingent during WWI. He was hit by an explosive bullet and lost his right arm. While recuperating in a hospital, he became pen-mate with Louisa Watson Small, a British writer. ... Louisa helped Harold write Private Peat (1917), a memoir of his experiences during World War I and after. ... The book was on the New York Times bestseller list in 1918 and 1919."
See sdrc.lib.uiowa.edu/traveling-culture/chau1/pdf/peat/2/bro... and archive.org/details/privatepeat00peatgoog

The Bridgeport times and evening farmer., February 08, 1918, Page 6, (in large ad at right) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn92051227/1918-02-08/ed-... has an ad for Indestructo scarves/ties (as above the conductor's head). "'Wrinkleless', 'Pinproof,' 'Indestructo.' Indestructo seems a word that is applied more often to trunks that receive very rough treatment, but indestructo applied to neckwear simply means that the particular weave of silk from which these scarves are made does not wrinkle, does not show markings made by scarf pins and is guaranteed three months wear without showing creases or worn spots. Almost every color is included." The ad in the photo says, "over a hundred solid colors." The newspaper ad also offers moire and paisley variants.

An ad in the Harrisburg telegraph., March 01, 1918, Page 17 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038411/1918-03-01/ed-... offers a written six month guarantee. Still at $1. In the Richmond times-dispatch., May 11, 1919, Page 5, bottom right chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045389/1919-05-11/ed-... the price is $1.50. The Washington times., June 04, 1920, FINAL EDITION, Page 3, (bottom left) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1920-06-04/ed-... has an ad that offers them at $1.45, claiming that $3 is the usual price!!

Mabel St Clair Stobart (1862 - 1954) www.iwm.org.uk/collections/item/object/205022514 www.dorsetlife.co.uk/2015/01/dorsets-wartime-heroine-mabe...

NYT of December 7, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0DE2DC1E3AE433A... indicates that she was in New York City, talking about the "Woman's Convoy," which she had organized, at the home of Mrs. Francis McNeil Bacon (the former Pauline Post). NYT of August 25, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C0DE4DD123FE433A... reported that she had arrived "at an Atlantic port" the previous day. "Mrs St. Clair Stobart, who holds the rank of Major in the Serbian Army and was the first woman to command a flying field hospital column at the front in war time ..."

More about her in NYT of November 14, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9906E6DF133FE433A... Daughter of Sir Samuel Boulton. Suffragist. Captured by Germans in 1914. Cornish tennis champion for three years in succession. She wrote a letter to the NYT editor, published in November 20, 1917 issue. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A03EFD9113AE433A...

Some biographical detail is at: ghgraham.org/stclairstobart1861.html She became a spiritualist and wrote on that topic in the 1920s. www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3403804349.html in an "Encyclopedia of Occultism and Parapsychology" suggests that her 1917-18 trip to the U.S. was on behalf of the British Ministry of Information. See www.leslieflint.com/mabel-st-clair-stobart for a conversation with her as a "spirit communicator."

Thanks swanq for the interesting details of Mabel St Clair Stobart's courageous work during World War I and for the reason she was in New York in 1917. This picture ran in the January, 1918 number of The Water Tower, with the description: "THE LAYING OF THE FIRST KEEL On Thursday December 20th [1917] at the Newark Bay Shipyard the first rivet was driven in the first standardized structural steel ship ever built. [...] The picture shows Mr John Hunter, representative of the United States Shipping Board, driving the first rivet after the center vertical keelson had been put in place. The gentleman standing immediately behind Mr Hunter in this picture is Mr Henry R Sutphen, vice president of the Submarine Boat Corporation and the man to whom credit for the production of the standardized structural steel ship is due." books.google.com/books?id=FAY0AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA48&lp...

Newark Bay Shipyard, 12/20/17, see "The General Manager of the Submarine Boat Corporation is Mr. B.L. Worden, president of the Lackawanna Bridge Co. He has labored with this proposition for many months and has silenced the critics who said it could not be done. The contract taken in September called for laying of keels in December and the crape hangers freely predicted that no keels would be laid before July. To his energy and foresight belong the credit for putting it over. At the little ceremony of the driving of the first rivet Mr Worden said 'You have seen this operation of driving the first rivet. It must be repeated 350,000 times before we launch this ship into the waters of the bay. Six more ships must be built on this way before our bit is done. Beyond you stretches for over half a mile the bulkhead fronting the waters of the bay. We are now seeking to complete the other ways and on each one of the twenty eight we must repeat this operation six times. Our task is unprecedented. These ships must be done in a length of time hitherto impossible. The dead steel that goes into these ships is to be converted into a scourge to the Huns, who now covet our fair land. We want these ships to go forth on errands of comfort to our soldiers and to bring consternation and confusion to our enemies." books.google.com/books?id=FAY0AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA48&lp...

Dancer and artist Paul Swan (1883–1972), "The most beautiful man in the world".

"Beauty and fame are fleeting and seem all the more so when possessed by one person as they were by poet, artist, and dancer Paul Swan. Quite forgotten today, Swan had an instinct for the right place and time to display his talents: on the vaudeville circuit in the teens, twenties, and thirties, in the Warhol crowd in the sixties. (Warhol filmed the elderly Swan creakily performing his campy, dancelike imitations of Greek heroes.) That instinct helped him to escape his dreary, rural Nebraska childhood home, a place deeply unpropitious to an artistic child with homosexual feelings; to make opportunities of what others found dead ends; and to propel himself from Chicago to New York and beyond, sometimes as a model, sometimes as an artist, always as a talented, resourceful American bohemian, wearing many hats to pay the rent while always returning to his easel. If Swan never painted a recognized masterpiece or choreographed a dance to equal those of Jerome Robbins or George Balanchine, the Londravilles' highly readable biography argues that, however minor, Swan matters."     -- Jack Helbig
Copyright © American Library Association. All rights reserved

An ensign on one of the small boats behind the bow of the launched ship looks to be Norwegian rather than Danish. The Danish flag has a white cross without a border stripe. The Norwegian has a dark blue cross with white border stripe. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Norway en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_Denmark Neither nation's flag has changed since the early 19th century, when Norway became independent of Denmark. So I think this pair of photos was taken in Norway and not Denmark. The name "Wilse" would confirm that. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anders_Beer_Wilse

Le Bien-être du Blessé was a war relief organization in WWI devoted to the dietary needs of soldiers. Its American president was Gertrude Atherton (1857-1948). This photo is probably from the Hero Land Bazaar in Nov.-Dec. 1917, given its placement in the Bain news stream and this letter from Gertrude Atherton about their booth at the Bazaar: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=950CEED9133BEE... Gertrude Atherton wrote about the organization in her book, The Living Present (1917): " BOOK I. FRENCHWOMEN IN WAR TIME CHAPTER XI. THE MARQUISE D'ANDIGNE The Marquise d'Andigne, who was Madeline Goddard of Providence, R.I., is President of Le Bien-Etre du Blesse, an oeuvre formed by Madame d'Haussonville at the request of the Ministere de la Guerre in May, 1915. She owes this position as president of one of the most important war relief organizations (perhaps after the Red Cross the most important) to the energy, conscientiousness, and brilliant executive abilities she had demonstrated while at the Front in charge of more than one hospital. She is an infirmiere major and was decorated twice for cool courage and resource under fire. The object of Le Bien-Etre du Blesse is to provide delicacies for the dietary kitchens of the hospitals in the War Zone, as many officers and soldiers had died because unable to eat eggs, or drink milk, the only two articles furnished by the rigid military system of the most conservative country in the world. The articles supplied by Le Bien-Etre du Blesse are very simple: condensed milk, sugar, cocoa, Franco-American soups, chocolate, sweet biscuits, jams, preserves, prunes, tea. Thousands of lives have been saved by Bien-Etre during the past year; for men who are past caring, or wish only for the release of death, have been coaxed back to life by a bit of jam on the tip of a biscuit, or a teaspoonful of chicken soup. Some day I shall write the full and somewhat complicated history of Le Bien-Etre du Blesse, quoting from many of Madame d'Andigne's delightful letters. But there is no space here and I will merely mention that my own part as the American President of Le Bien-Etre du Blesse is to provide the major part of the funds with which it is run, lest any of my readers should be tempted to help me out." www.readbookonline.net/read/37964/75094/ see

Edward William "Eddie" Mahan (January 19, 1892 – July 22, 1975) was an American football player. While playing halfback for Harvard, Mahan was selected as a first-team All-American three consecutive years from 1913–1915. He was widely regarded as one of the greatest football players in the first 50 years of the sport and was named by Jim Thorpe as the greatest football player of all time. In 1951, he was elected to the College Football Hall of Fame as part of the first group of inductees. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddie_Mahan

Camp Douglas was established in October 1862 as a small military garrison about three miles east of Salt Lake City, Utah, for the purpose of protecting the overland mail route and telegraph lines along the Central Overland Route. In 1878, the post was renamed Fort Douglas. The fort was officially closed in 1991,[3] and most of the buildings were turned over to the University of Utah. A small section of the original fort is used by the Army Reserve and includes the Fort Douglas Military Museum. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Douglas

From the Wikipedia entry: "During World War I, Higginson and the BSO's music director Karl Muck were the focus of public controversy when the orchestra failed to add the Star-Spangled Banner to its concerts as other orchestras did. Muck's ties to the German Kaiser made for exaggerated press coverage, but Higginson was the particular focus of criticism. The New York Times called him "obstinate" for his refusal to allow public sentiment to affect programming. The orchestra's publicity agent, writing years later, blamed Muck's eventual internment as an enemy alien on the "short-sighted stubbornness" of Higginson and the orchestra's manager Charles A. Ellis on the anthem issue." For some of the press coverage, see Norwich bulletin., November 03, 1917, Page 15, col 4. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014086/1917-11-03/ed-...

S.S. Saga, Mooremack's first passenger operation left for South America. The Saga was built in 1909 in Newcastle, England, by Swan, Hunter & Wigham Richardson, and was of 2,809 gross tons. She was of steel, 322.4 feet long, 46.2 feet beam and 19.5 feet draft. She had a well deck and two other decks, had electric lights and refrigerating equipment. Enrico Caruso was her most famous passenger. www.moore-mccormack.com/Cargo-Liners/SS-Saga.htm
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enrico_Caruso

The Union times. volume, November 10, 1917, DAILY EDITION, page 1, right-hand column chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/2014226285/1917-11-10/ed-... indicates that Caruso had just arrived back from South America having been away six months. He was met by Giulio Gatti-Casazza, Antonio Scotti, and Andrea de Segurela of the Metropolitan Opera Company. The last is presumably en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrés_de_Segurola

New-York tribune., November 05, 1917, Page 9, column 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1917-11-05/ed-... reports that he was indeed on the Saga. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045389/1917-11-05/ed-... indicates that the arrival was on Nov. 4. The press is not reporting the port of arrival (presumably for reasons of security), but given that colleagues from the Met. greeted him on the dock, I assume he landed somewhere in New York harbor.
De Segurola wore glasses.  It might be him on the left or at the back.

From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernestine_Schumann-Heink "During World War I, Schumann-Heink supported the United States and its armed forces. She entertained the troops and raised money to help wounded veterans. She toured the United States raising money for the war effort, although she had relatives fighting on both sides of the war – including her sons August Heink, a merchant sailor who had been impressed into the German submarine service, son Walter Schumann, Henry Heink and George Washington Schumann, all in the United States Navy."

The evening world., November 05, 1917, Final Edition, Page 25, col. 1. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1917-11-05/ed-... indicates that her only recital in New York "this season" was at Carnegie Hall the previous Saturday, November 3. One of her sons, a sailor, was in the audience. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/search/pages/results/?state=&a... suggests that she had been on a whistle-stop tour visiting her soldier sons and singing at benefits. Her pianist was Edith Evans and a soprano, Florence French, also performed. So maybe the younger woman is one of them.
Thank you swanq for the additional information about Schumann-Heink. Wish we could identify the other woman in the stylish white outfit. Thanks for suggesting some possible candidates!

This is appears to be (then (1921?)) Major Harry L. Smith (United States Marine Corps). He earned the Navy Cross for valor during the Great War and was quite the marksman. See information regarding Smith and his Marine Corps career at this site describing his since-sold USMC Marksmanship badge: 1914 USMC OFFICER ENGRAVED EXPERT USN SHOOTING AWARD MEDAL, FAMED USMC SHOOTING INSTRUCTOR & 1924 OLYMPICS HAITI COACH This is a historical engraved medal named to one of the top shots ever in the Marine Corps, Harry L. Smith. Smith served from 1909 to 1945 in various capacities but is most famous for being captain of the US Marine Rifle Team in the 1920's and winning multiple shooting championships. In 1924, along with Douglas MacDougal (leader of the Guarde D'Haiti and later general, see photo below), he trained and led the first ever Haitian Rifle Team into the 1924 Paris Olympics where the team won the bronze medal. The Haitians were are part of the Garde D'Haiti or Haitian Gendarmerie that the US Marines trained well into the late 1920's. Smith went on to become a Colonel and train thousands of Marine marksman. In 1919 he was recommended for a Navy Cross by BGen Eli Cole for contributing materially to the war effort, by ensuring that 90% of all recruits coming out of Paris Island in 1918 were qualified with the rifle. The Marines gained a reputation in France and Germany during WW1 for their oustanding marksmanship. He also was influential in the Marine Corps adaptation of the M1918 Browning Automatic Rifle. The medal is a 1914 dated US Navy Sharpshooter medal that has an expert bar attached that is engraved "LIEUT. H.L. SMITH. U.S.M.C.". The planchet is engraved the same. The medal suspension is marked "THE HAYES BROS. CO". A wonderful and attributed medal to one of the best Marine marksmen of all time. Smith served with distinction during the Great War, earning the Navy Cross. See: Congressional Medal of Honor, the Distinguished Service Cross and the Distinguished Service Medal Issued by the War Department Since April 6, 1917: Up to and Including General Orders, No. 126, War Department, November 11, 1919 United States. Adjutant-General's Office U.S. Government Printing Office, 1920 Page 360 Harry L. Smith, first lieutenant, 13th Machine Gun Battalion. For extraordinary heroism in action near Cunel, France, October 14, 1918. Leaving his shelter in a shallow machine-gun emplacement, accompanied by one soldier, Lieut. Smith ventured forth through a most intense fire to the air of a wounded officer, and assisted in carrying him a distance of 170 yards to safety. Residence at appointment: Lucedale Miss.

Irving Tar Bush (July 12, 1869 – October 21, 1948) was an American businessman. His father was the wealthy industrialist, oil refinery owner, and yachtsman Rufus T. Bush. As founder of the Bush Terminal Company, Irving T. Bush was responsible for the construction of the massive Bush Terminal transportation, warehousing, and manufacturing facility in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, New York City which employed more than 25,000 people within its boundaries. Bush also commissioned Manhattan's landmark Bush Tower skyscraper on 42nd Street next to Times Square and funded the construction of Bush House in London. A prolific author, his life and works attracted attention from the national press, influential figures, and major publishers and journalists. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irving_T._Bush
NYT of November 7, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9505E6D9123FE433A... reports that he had just been appointed Executive Director of the New York Port War Board.

Jascha Heifetz (/ˈhaɪfɪts/; February 2 [O.S. January 20] 1901 – December 10, 1987) was a violinist, widely considered to be one of the finest violinists of modern times. Born in Vilnius, Russian Empire (now Lithuania), he moved as a teenager to the United States, where his Carnegie Hall debut was rapturously received. The New York Times called him "perhaps the greatest violinist of all time." Fritz Kreisler, another leading violinist of the twentieth century, said on hearing Heifetz's debut, "We might as well take our fiddles and smash them across our knees." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jascha_Heifetz

Amazing photo

The British Mark IV Tank "Britannia". Believe it or not, this tank is still extant and in the process of being restored. From, The Measurement and Modeling of a World War I Mark IV Tank Using CLR and CCD Camera/Line Scanning Systems in an Outside Environment: After the Battle of Arras, Liberty and its crew were sent to America for exhibition and to help sell war bonds. During a 2-hr event in Syracuse, NY, the tank raised $868.45 (the equivalent of $13,221.12 today). The purchase of a war thrift stamp allowed one to view the tank up close. For the larger purchase of a war stamp for $4.15 ($63.12 today), one was allowed into the vehicle’s interior, presumably with a guided tour from the crew. It was sometime during this American tour that the crew changed the tank’s name from “Britannia” to “Liberty.” Appropriately, the tank and its crew were also the main attraction in the Liberty Day Parade in New York City. ... Liberty found its final home in 1919 when it was taken to northeastern Maryland and added to the collection of the newly established Ordnance Museum at Aberdeen Proving Ground, MD ... . Since that time, it has remained one of the museum’s cornerstone attractions and has stood as a reminder of the significant advancements that have been made in armored warfare over the past century. Also, this tank is the subject of a Flickr album created by Flickr user Charlie Webb: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/cmwebbjr/sets/72157634959239855/]

TVL 1970: Unbelievable that this tank still exists! Thank you for all the information and the link to the paper on the Liberty's history and the current scanning and restoration project. B-59: Thank you for the better date for the parade.  We will add more details when we update.

Clearly at the Polo Grounds, and from the proximity of other World Series 1917 photos, perhaps they were the pregame entertainment for one of the New York games. The Subway Band was formed from employees of Interborough Rapid Transit (IRT). From Modern Hospital magazine, 1916: " Subway Band The company has a band of 100 employees known as the subway band properly uniformed and equipped which plays at various special and other functions of the employees and has grown into one of the best musical organizations of the city of New York While its uses are generally restricted to company affairs it occasionally participates in patriotic and civic functions frequently furnishing the musical service at Sunday night church concerts on which occasions employees generally attend and for the last three years has acted as escort to the Grand Army to and from their annual church service The general object sought in the formation of the band was to place at the disposal of such of our employees as are musically inclined means for further study and practice of music as well as to inspire loyalty and patriotism Every man connected with the band is taught discipline and every member is on his honor to carry this discipline study into his every day life and work to be courteous to passengers and to preach the subject of good service to the traveling public and to every other subway employee for whose general benefit the band was created The company has provided the band with meeting and rehearsal rooms and as those rooms are located at one of the important terminals of the company employees are in the habit of gathering there on rehearsal nights to enjoy the music." books.google.com/books?id=fDchAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA139&l...
Thanks for the interesting information about the band and the likely context for their performance. We'll add information to the description.

"Katharine Faulkner "Kay" Swift (April 19, 1897 – January 28, 1993) was an American composer of popular and classical music, the first woman to completely score a hit musical. Written in 1930, Fine and Dandy includes some of her best known songs; the title song has become a jazz standard. "Can't We Be Friends?" (1929) was her biggest hit song. Swift also arranged some of the music of George Gershwin posthumously, such as the prelude "Sleepless Night" (1946)." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kay_Swift

www.thechinastory.org/ritp/fan-yuan-lien-fan-yuanlian-%E8... In 1917 he was MInister of Education in China.

范源濂（1876年－1927年12月23日），字静生，中国教育家，湖南湘阴人，为中国民族化工实业家范旭东兄长。

1898年就读于长沙时务学堂，师从梁启超。戊戌变法失败后，两次东渡日本求学。中华民国成立后，出任南京临时政府教育次长、总长，国民政府教育总长。1921年曾以教育总长的名义发表言论，反对教会学校学生强制做礼拜和读《圣经》。1925年任中华教育文化基金董事会(中基会)首任干事长，1926年任北京师范大学校长。1927年12月23日在天津病逝。

范源濂去世后，由中国著名动物学家秉志和植物学家胡先骕所创办的静生生物调查所，以他命名，纪念范源濂对中国生物学研究的赞助和提倡。后来的中国科学院动物研究所和植物研究所是自静生生物调查所衍生而出。

I'd be interested in knowing if the designation as "German packing house" indicates it to be located in Germany, during WWI, or simply a meat packing operation owned/run/manned by Germans in the USA? Sinclair Lewis published THE JUNGLE in 1906, and sentiments were high over the conditions in that industry, still a political issue in 1915 I'm sure. It looks gross enough to turn anyone into a vegetarian.

moccasinlanding: The caption "German packing house" was original to the photograph, so the meaning is not altogether clear. However, in browsing other photos filed near this one, there are a number of images taken in Germany, and one related to Doeberitz, a German prisoner of war camp near Berlin. The photos filed nearby in this collection are not always related to each other, but sometimes can offer clues. Without further research, my best guess is that this photo was taken in Germany rather than the U.S.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/kristi_loc] Thank you for your response. I believe I saw the one you mention re Doeberitz POW camp. Not sure, but both could be "public relations" efforts to counteract reports of food shortages, especially those related to POWs.

This, like some of the surrounding photos is dated 10-1-17, the last game of the Sox' regular season, in New York to play the Yankees at the Polo Grounds. A Bain team picture would be unusual but for the fact that the Sox were in first place and poised to begin the World Series on October 6th against the New York Giants.
