The 1917 Victor Records Catalog has this entry for him: GLENN WILFRED Bass Mr Glenn is a native of California and was born on one of the great ranches in the San Joaquin Valley He began his studies in San Francisco but when the phenomenal quality of his voice was realized he was induced by his friends to go to New York for further study He made rapid progress under a number of noted teachers and now has a remarkable range of some two and a half octaves from C below the bass clef to F sharp Mr Glenn is soloist of the Cathedral of St John the Harlem Reformed Church in New York and the Lotus Glee Club and appears with many other organizations during the season e Victor realizing that here was one of the finest basso profundo voices in America promptly secured his exclusive record services for a number of years books.google.com/books?id=tnhFAQAAMAAJ&dq=wilfred+gle...

"National Red Cross Pageant (1917) is an all-star revue silent film, now considered a lost film,directed by Christy Cabanne. On October 5, 1917, a live open-air pageant was held on a private estate, Rosemary Farm, near Huntington, New York. The event was mainly the brainchild of Ben Ali Haggin, famous as a stage designer. His wife appears in one of the episodes. The earnings from the live pageant itself went to the Red Cross. Presumably the filming of the pageant was made with a patriotic fervor in the wake of the United States entry into World War I in April 1917. The proceeds from the film going to the war effort, such as the Red Cross, War Bonds, etc." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Red_Cross_Pageant

Thanks B-59, for all the links. I did some additional searching since I wanted to determine which Innes-Ker this was. In the October 15, 1917 edition of "The Spur", a photo very similar to this, obviously taken at the save event was published. Its caption says this is Lord Robert Innes-Ker and Mrs. Joseph Sampson Stevens. The event is an annual horse show held at Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, NY, with the money raised going to the Red Cross. From another source, "The Saddle and Horse Show Chronicle", I found the dates for the show were September 20th and 21st. From other newspaper articles I read that Lord Robert Innes-Ker was in New York to help enlist people for the Royal Flying Corps.
With some additional searching I discovered that Mrs. Stevens is the former Clara Sherwood Rollins.
Should an alternate title/caption be added of Ker rather than Kerr?  Or Innes-Ker?

Frank Arthur Vanderlip, Sr. (November 17, 1864 – June 30, 1937) was an American banker. He was Assistant Secretary of the Treasury from 1897-1901 and was president of the National City Bank from 1909 to 1919. Vanderlip created the Scarborough School at his property, Beechwood in Briarcliff Manor, New York and founded the 16,000-acre-area (6,500 ha) collectively known as Palos Verdes, California. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_A._Vanderlip

The sign says a serving is 35 pfennig, or 35 cents in German currency -- so roughly a 4:1 exchange rate against the dollar.  It went up to a million to one and more in post-war inflation, so that same goulash in the early 1920's would have cost ~90,000 marks.

Edith T. Gracie (Edith Temple Gracie) (1894-1918) the only daughter of Colonel Archibald Gracie IV (1858-1912), and Mrs. Constance Elise Gracie (née Schack) (1852-1937) was a survivor of the Titanic disaster in 1912 along with her mother and father.   One of her ancestors built Gracie Mansion which would later become the official residence of the mayor of New York City in 1942. She was introduced to society in 1912, and in December 1917, married Captain Dunbar Adams (Dunbar Burchell Adams) (1891-1928), son of Mr. John Dunbar Adams (1849-1934) and Mrs. Susan Burchell Adams (1867-1937). Edith died of pneumonia Dec 31, 1918, after being married one year. Her husband was in the service in France and unaware of her death. She was 24 years old. Her husband, Dunbar, died of pneumonia at the age of 37. – Compiled [1] [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] [9] There are 4 other photographs of Miss Edith T. A. Gracie in the Harris & Ewing Collection at the Library of Congress. So far I haven't found a reference to the initial "A", in the caption of "Edith T. A. Gracie". A photograph of Dunbar Adams, c.1910, with Beatrice Woerz is in the Library of Congress Collection on Flickr. "Beatrice Woerz with Dunbar Adams c.1910"

After Colonel Archibald Gracie’s rescue from the sinking of the Titanic, by the SS Carpathia, he recognized that he had been an eyewitness to a major historical event, and began to immediately record the events of the sinking while still aboard the Carpathia, and at countless inquiries in the months following. He was not in a lifeboat with the "women and children", but later jumped into the Atlantic with a life preserver. He reportedly was haunted by the ordeal for the rest of his life. After his death, his completed manuscript "The Truth about the Titanic," was published, later republished as, "Titanic, A Survivor's Story." [1] [2] [3]

From looking at additional attributed source material on that site, as well as a look at the Encyclopedia Titanica it appears that the Times was in error.

Lina Cavalieri (1874-1944) ‏was an opera singer. She was married to Robert Winthrop Chanler and they divorced in 1912. viaf.org/viaf/74927750/#Cavalieri,_Lina,_1874-1944

an opera singer … and married to some guy... Seriously? Natalina "Lina" Cavalieri was a renowned Italian opera soprano singer and actress – and was famously married four times. She had an extraordinary range of talents and achievements that took her from a singer in a café to the dizzying heights of the Metropolitan Opera House. Cavalieri’s stage début was as Nedda in I Pagliacci in Lisbon. Five years later she was singing Fedora with Enrico Caruso in Paris, which, together, they took to the Metropolitan Opera a year later. The Met contracted her to debut in Fedora for $1,000 a night opposite Caruso – a sum far exceeded that paid to Geraldine Farrar, the Met’s reigning diva. She was frequently described as "the world's most beautiful woman" – and was likely the most photographed woman of her time, appearing in hundreds of magazines in America and throughout Europe – and she was a "Palmolive girl" which featured full-page advertisements of her giving beauty tips. Lina Cavalieri became the first opera star to successfully make the transition from the lyric opera to the silent screen and she made nearly a dozen American and Italian films. After her death, her extraordinary life story was adapted as stage play and film. Garbo played a version of her, renamed as "Madame Rita Cavallini" in Romance (1930), and she was played by Gina Lollobrigida in the 1955 film La donna più bella del mondo.

The arch is en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Square_Arch "a marble triumphal arch built in 1892 in Washington Square Park in the Greenwich Village neighborhood of Lower Manhattan in New York City. It celebrates the centennial of George Washington's inauguration as President of the United States in 1789 and forms the grand southern terminus of Fifth Avenue." A banner reads, "Boyce's Tigers." See for a picture of the Boyce who trained the Tigers. www.newyorker.com/magazine/1940/09/28/renascent-tigers gives his first name as Adolphe.

NYT of Sept 3, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F00EFDB103BE03AB... indicated that parades of drafted men were to be held the following day simultaneously in Manhattan, the Bronx, and Brooklyn. Captain A.L. Boyce, U.S.R., marshal of the parade would meet the reserve officers who were to assist him at 9:30 am under the Washington Arch to deliver final instructions. NYT of Sept 4, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B00E7DA103BE03AB... has more details, and indicates that Boyce's Tigers were the one draft contingent who had received training at this point, drilling on Governor's Island.

Major Adolphe Lippig Boyce, M.D. (1866-1955) was the commander of Boyce's Tigers, a paramilitary group. He trained civilians on Governor's Island prior to World War I and New York City Center prior to World War II.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_gun "The Lewis gun (or Lewis automatic machine gun or Lewis automatic rifle) is a World War I-era light machine gun of American design that was perfected and widely used by the British Empire. It was first used in combat in World War I, and continued in service with a number of armed forces through to the end of the Korean War. It is visually distinctive because of its wide tubular cooling shroud around the barrel and its top-mounted drum-pan magazine."

"The legacy of two Irish tenors to Connecticut: John McCormack and Peter Dolan" -- digitalcommons.sacredheart.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?articl... suggests a likely location for this batch of McCormack photos. The article suggests that in 1917, he and Lily bought Rocklea in Noroton (a section of Darien), CT. There is also mention of a farm that he called Lilydale and a 40-foot boat Macushla. However, I'm not sure that the boat here would be as long as 40 feet.

I'm channeling [https://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02] by adding tags to these McCormack photos based on the research of  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] on these photos as well as the earlier McCormack photos [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] has referenced.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05], The New York Times reported the sale of Lilidale on February 26, 1922. I don’t yet know if that’s what’s shown in this LOC photograph, although I would think it likely. “John McCormack, the well-known tenor, sold the estate known as Lillydale [sic] Farm, at Noroton, Conn., consisting of 163 acres of farm and woodland, to the Highland Farm Company of Darien, Conn. who, in turn, has leased it to the Ox Ridge Hunt Club for a long terms of years.” – The New York Times (This information is also included in the reference [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] provided above: digitalcommons.sacredheart.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?articl... ) The Ox Ridge Hunt Club exists to this day, and the link is to a “history page” referencing John McCormack. (albeit they misspell the name as McCormick – pleasing neither the McCormacks' or the McCormicks'  ;)

As identified by [https://www.flickr.com/photos/66311327@N05] and [https://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] in other photos (below), John Brown [1881 -1967] was born in Scotland and came to America at the age of 2. He attended public schools in Brooklyn and had a series of jobs that led him to the staff of the Metropolitan Opera Company, where he was the business controller from 1910-1916. In addition to his position with the opera company, he was Assistant Secretary of the New Theatre, Assistant Secretary of the Metropolitan Opera Company, President and business manager of the Metropolitan Ballet Company and Secretary-Treasurer of the Century Amusement Company. He resigned simultaneously from all of those offices in 1916, and went into partnership with Alphonse G. Kaufmann of the Peugeot Auto Import Company in New York. Later he was the eastern representative for the Chicago Opera Company and managed concert artists, and was business manager of the American Operatic and Allied Arts Foundation. In 1925, he was appointed business manager of Carnegie Hall, where he served until 1929. – Compiled from The New York Times and Carnegie Hall [1] [2] [3] [4]

Walter Hines Page (August 15, 1855 – December 21, 1918), United States ambassador to the United Kingdom during World War I en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Hines_Page See also www.flickr.com/photos/8623220@N02/6266477402/

On his speech in Plymouth (England): "Of the series of speeches that stand to his credit in England probably the one that will be longest remembered is that delivered at Plymouth on August 4, 1917, the third anniversary of the war. This not only reviewed the common history of the two nations for three hundred years, and suggested a programme for making the bonds tighter yet, but it brought the British public practical assurances as to America's intentions in the conflict. Up to that time there had been much vagueness and doubt; no official voice had spoken the clear word for the United States; the British public did not know what to expect from their kinsmen overseas. But after Page's Plymouth speech the people of Great Britain looked forward with complete confidence to the cooperation of the two countries and to the inevitable triumph of this cooperation." -THE LIFE AND LETTERS OF WALTER H. PAGE, BY BURTON J. HENDRICK 1923 www.gwpda.org/memoir/Page/Page15.htm

Kermit Roosevelt MC (October 10, 1889 – June 4, 1943) was a son of U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt. He was a graduate of Harvard University, a soldier serving in two world wars (with both the British and American Armies), a businessman, and a writer who explored two continents with his father. He fought a lifelong battle with depression and alcoholism, ultimately leading to suicide while serving in Alaska during World War II. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kermit_Roosevelt

See davidowens.typepad.com/asian_images/2008/08/golden-madonn... which includes a postcard of the balancing madonna, captioned Albert (Somme) Basilique de Notre Dame de Brebieres. "The omnipresent hanging Madonna and Child statue gave birth to a contemporary legend amongst the British and German troops at the Somme. Many soldiers believed that the war would end when the statue fell to the ground. Since this outcome might have given rise to unrealistic, and perhaps undesirable, expectations regarding the end of the war, the British firmly wired the lurching Madonna to the remains of the tower. Armies would determine the war, not divine intervention."

A cropped version of this photo (with the same story) appeared in East Oregonian, April 16, 1918, DAILY EVENING EDITION, Image 4 oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn88086023/1918-04-16/ed-1/se... The same photo was in - The Chattanooga news., April 04, 1918, Late Edition, Page 14 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038531/1918-04-04/ed-... - The Washington herald., April 02, 1918, Page 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045433/1918-04-02/ed-... and several other newspapers. The fate of the statue is described in the Iron County register., January 09, 1919, Image 2, 'FALL OF STATUE ENDS HUN LUCK' chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024283/1919-01-09/ed-...

Mrs. Nicholas Biddle née Sarah Lippincott (1894–1962), was a daughter of Joshua Bertram Lippincott (1857-1940) and Joanna (née Wharton) Lippincott (1858-1938). One of her grandfathers, Joshua Bertram Lippincott (1857-1940), founded the J. B. Lippincott & Company, publishers, and the other, Joseph Wharton (1826-1909), founded the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, co-founded the Bethlehem Steel company, and was one of the founders of Swarthmore College. On February 11, 1915, she married Nicholas Biddle (1893–1977), son of Edward Biddle III (1851-1933) and Lillian Howard Lee (1862-1946). He graduated from Princeton University in 1916 and went into the insurance business. Nicholas served a lifelong term with the National Guard, was active in both World Wars, and his service with the Army reserves earned him the rank of Brigadier General. Nicholas Biddle was a well-noted, big-game hunter and was commissioned to travel the world and bring back specimens; some of his ‘trophies’ still reside at the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University. Nicholas and Sarah had three sons, Nicholas Biddle, Jr. (1917-2013), John Scott Biddle (1925-2008), and Wharton G. Biddle (b.1928); and two daughters, Sarah Lee Biddle (Mrs. William F. Stokes, Jr.) (1921-2014), and Joanna Wharton Biddle (Mrs. Lewis Johnson) (1915-2008). Presuming the publishing date of c.1915, Mrs. Biddle is likely holding her daughter Joanna. This is V. L. Chrisler (Vivian Leroy Chrisler, 1885-1953), an acoustics researcher at the National Bureau of Standards, Washington, DC, looking over a loud-speaker horn used in sound penetration tests. Above the horn is an opening in the ceiling in which is fitted a slab of the building material to be tested. Over the horn is hanging a telephone receiver used in testing the amount of noise. A similar receiver is hung in the room above, over the slab. – Information excerpted from press notes/caption that accompanied a companion photo to this one, (that cannot be posted) showing Dr. E. A. Eckhardt (Engelhardt August Eckhardt, b1885) and his assistant V. L. Chrisler. I will post a link to an authoritative source for that companion photo when/if I locate one. An additional photograph of V.L. Chrisler at work studying the "echo effect" of a room is in the Harris & Ewing collection of The Library of Congress. V. L. Chrisler • "The Man in the Box"

I am not positive, but I believe this airplane engine was adapted for agricultural use. The wind generated was used to prevent frost from forming on crops. The same technique was also used to keep birds from eating certain crops at harvest time.
I like Christian's idea. Notice there are some wheel chocks to keep the back wheels from rolling.

The engine resembles an Hispano-Suiza 8 aero engine in a V-8 arrangement. (The engine would have been common in US stocks, as it powered a number of US military aircraft and it was produced under-license by the Wright Company). What is unusual for the era (if the 1922 photo date is correct) is that the engine appears to be driving an adjustable or variable pitch propeller - which is a type that would have been a cutting-edge technology under development during the time. Given that information, I can say with an almost certainty that this is a photograph illustrating a demonstration of the Paragon Adjustable and Reversible Propeller, most probably at or near Bolling Field in Washington, D.C. The December 1922 Aerial Age Weekly (Vol. 15, Pages 585-589) details the apparatus and the adjustable pitch propeller demonstrated, note also the photos on page 588 of the linked article which appears to show the test stand photographed above. Also, after examining the finer resolution TIFF version of this photo at the LOC site linked above, it would appear that Spencer Heath (1876-1963), the man who developed the variable pitch propeller being demonstrated, is the bearded man in the white (or light colored) coat leaning over the controls in the photo. Here is another photo of Heath: www.cooperative-individualism.org/photograph_heath-spence... Spencer Heath distinguished himself in a number of varied fields. See his Wikipedia entry: Spencer Heath From Aerial Age Weekly, (December 1922, Vol. 15, Pages 585-589): Paragon Adjustable and Reversible Propeller
The Paragon adjustable and reversible aircraft propeller, the invention of Spencer Heath, the pioneer propeller maker, made its official debut on October 11 at Bolling Field in a demonstration to representatives of the offices of the Chief of Air Service, Chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics of the Navy, of the Air Mail, the Press and motion picture news associations. The automobile truck trailer, upon which the propeller and a 150 h.p. Wright-Hispano engine was mounted, was made to maneuver about Bolling Field at the will of the operator. What new stunts may now be evolved with the aid of a reversing propeller may be left to the imagination. One can easily imagine the two-seater of the future suddenly reversing into a stall and taking a shot from underneath at his surprised adversary overhead. The device is to the aircraft what change speed gears are to the automobile. . . . Demonstration Under Power To show the action under power the propeller has been installed on a 150 H.P. Hispano-Suiza engine mounted with gasoline tank, observers’ seats, etc., on a trailer truck weighing about two tons which is free to roll on the ground. In the demonstrations thus far made the device is put through its entire range of performance, which includes disconnecting the pitch limiting mechanism so that the blade angels are controlled throughout a compete revolution of 360 degrees, both forward and reverse. With the engine turning at 1500 r.p.m. the angular change from full speed ahead to full speed astern is accomplished in about 3-1/3 seconds.
Excellent work.. that's definitely the same thing pictured in the December, 1922 Aerial Age.

The pensive guy is holding a small slab of marble, or some other veined stone. It looks like the big wheel is designed to clamp a whole series of slabs of the same size into a rotating jig. In the high-res view you can see the slabs are a few different varieties of stone. It's a little hard to see what those roller-like things underneath are doing; but perhaps there's a spinning drum to grind or polish the surfaces of the slabs.
Perhaps someone was testing and comparing types of stone for abrasion-resistance. Selecting which one to use for stair treads in public buildings?

The slabs look mostly like marble (which is not a great choice for stairs btw.) Nonetheless, perhaps they wanted to find the hardest batches. Maybe one of the rollers underneath is in fact some kind of abrasion tester.  Floors could be another application.

A Bureau of Standards publication from 1933 is titled Wear Resistance of Natural Stone Flooring nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/jres/11/jresv11n5p635_A2b.pdf A quick skim suggests this report shows and describes different equipment and tests but does confirm that the agency did related work.

Found! "A study of problems relating to the maintenance of interior marble." Technologic Papers of the Bureau of Standards, (1927) T 350 Photo on page 609. archive.org/stream/studyofproblem1927350kess#page/609/mod... Author is Daniel W. Kessler. See stonewall.nist.gov/CONTENT/About.htm

LoC has a photo of Kessler in this room in another collection: www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/npcc.27051/ Captioned "D.W. Kessler, Bu. of Standards testing granite and marble, 5/13/25" It seems likely that it is Kessler in this H&E photo, but he can't be seen well enough for me to be sure. Looking further in the National Photo collection, I find a picture that seems very similar to the H&E photo here. www.loc.gov/pictures/item/npc2008007637/resource/ captioned "D.W. Kessler, Bu. of Standards, scrubbing marble, 6/9/25"
Oh, excellent! Sounds like the scrubber drum was felt rather than abrasive; the test was whether cleaning solutions would cause the stone to break down.

More info on Daniel W. Kessler. An industry organization created an award in his name, and their site provides some biographical information: "This Society Recognized Committee Award has been established by ASTM Committee C18 on Dimension Stone in honor of the late Daniel W. Kessler. Mr. Kessler joined ASTM in 1926 during the formation of Committee C18 and was very active until his retirement in 1952 as Chief of the Building; Stone Section of the National Bureau of Standards. During his tenure at the Bureau, Mr. Kessler became a nationally known expert in the field of natural stones and their utilization." www.astm.org/MEMBERSHIP/filtrexx40.cgi?-P+AC+30+guideline... From a genealogical site: "Daniel W. Kessler, 20 AUG 1883 - 9 SEP 1962 Index Burial: Place: Fort Lincoln Cemetery, Brentwood, MD Individual Note: From the Washington Post. September 12, 1962 - "Daniel W. Kessler, 79, retired chief of the Building Stone Section of the National Bureau of Standards, died Sunday at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 2031 Rosemont ave. nw. He joined the Weather Bureau in 1912 and transferred to the Bureau of Standards several years later. While at the bureau, he invented machines and laboratory equipment for testing building materials. He is survived by his wife, Lotta Logan Kessler; two daughters, Virginia Weise, of 5447 Alta Vista rd., Bethesda, and Louise Clark of Roanoke, and a son, Edwin, who lives in California." www.gustner-wright-genealogy.com/tree/np201.htm

Another photo of Kessler with this machine in the background (called "Apparatus Used For Making Long Period Scrubbing Tests on Marble" in the 1927 report cited by swanq) from the LOC National Photo Co. collection, titled "D.W. Kessler, Bu. of Standards, scrubbing marble, [6/9/25]" www.loc.gov/pictures/item/npc2008007638/

This device is a Theremin. A musical instrument developed by Leon Theremin. It generates tones by moving ones hands through a magnetic field. Very popular in science fiction films and used by the Beach Boys in their song "Good Vibrations".

Leon Theremin did not bring his instrument to the US until 1927 or so. And it looked very different from this. More like a wooden lectern, with a horizontal loop to control volume and a vertical wand to control pitch.

Given the date, I think this picture was taken by the photographer to illustrate a story about the lawsuit between Edward Howard Armstrong and Lee De Forest, which had a date in the U.S. Supreme Court in 1928 over who owned the rights and invented the superheterodyne (regenerative) radio receiver. There was a long, involved set of lawsuits involving De Forest and Armstrong, also involving RCA and Westinghouse, over ownership of patents involved in the development of early radio.  If you look at photos of De Forest and Armstrong in the 1928 era, you'll see they are all using loop antennas (very similar to above) to demonstrate their radio technology in their labs.

Also, likely not just RDF as there are three units in the photo: on the left, a power supply (battery?); the middle unit (I would guess a receiver as the operator appears to be tuning around to receive a signal), and the right side unit (give it appears to have a plate and load control for a vacuum tube, typical with a transmitter).  Also looks to be homebrewed equipment built by the operator, not commercial gear (at least none that survives to the modern era on the various collector websites). At that time, the transmitter also probably would only have a single frequency, hence the lack of frequency control on that transmitter box.

We recently found some Harris & Ewing catalog cards which have captions for some photos that were previously uncaptioned. Our commenters did a good job of figuring this one out, but Harris & Ewing's caption for this photo was:

ORIGINAL MODEL OF FIRST ICE MACHINE NOW ON DISPLAY AT SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION. Washington, D.C. Aug 7--while millions are enjoying iced drinks these torrid days very few of them know who invented the first ice-making machine. It was Dr. John Gorrie of Florida, who in 1836, got the idea because he had several few patients under his care and believed that fever, could be reduced and benefited by cold. Before 1836 ice was cut from the rivers during the winters and stored for summer use but according to the oldtimers the supply ran out along about the 29th of July. Dr. Gorrie spent his entire personal fortune attempting to develop his idea. And he died without realizing that he would some day be recognized as a great benefactor of mankind. The original of the first model of the ice machine is now on view at the Smithsonian Institution and is shown in this picture with K.M. Perry, engineering division of the Smithsonian. 8-7-39
Aw, hats off to Dr. Gorrie, and thanks for the update! (Ha, my beardy ancestor once made considerable profit sawing ice out of Lake Ontario.)

Generating electricity with with a  cornstarch powered engine?

Are there any other images in the LoC collection that might help identify the location in the background? What I'm seeing here is that a 4-cylinder engine block has been repurposed for some kind of testing—removing the normal cylinder head and adding two tall chambers (and are they, metal, or …?) The man is sprinkling powder into the two active exhaust ports, and I can't quite read whether it's baking powder, baking soda, "baker's pride" cornstarch… ? The things that look like spark plugs are not connected to any typical automotive coil/rotor—but instead, to some kind of house current lamp socket—maybe using the tall lamps as voltage dividers? Could they be glow plugs?

We recently found some old catalog cards for Harris & Ewing that had a caption for this photo. The caption for this photo should be: 

"May be possible to run family "flivver" on corn starch, after extensive experimenting, the United States Department of Agriculture has discovered a way to run an automobile engine on the dust of corn starch. In fact, the grains of almost any wood will do the work. In this photograph, W.A. Noel of the Department is shown with the engine used for the experiments."
Early rebreather gear (with CO2 capture media)?
The "Momsen Lung" : en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Momsen
Bill Forbes is correct. Used for self rescue from sunken subs. The chamber in the rear was flooded and used for training. This was probably taken in New London, CT.

This may be a comparison test between the different rebreather devices which were available. The right-hand man looks to be wearing the British Davis Submerged Escape Apparatus (more detailed photos here). There are quite a few others made in the US in this list which I haven't checked yet. Many images of the Momsen Lung itself show dual air hoses coming out of the mouthpiece.
On the left, maybe the German Dräger Gegenlunge granted a 1932 US patent.

Ah, now I do see other images identified as a Momsen Lung which look like the center apparatus (squarish and connected directly to a single mouthpiece). An eBay auction of a 1938 press photo shows what seems to be the middle apparatus (note the weird alligator clips on the straps). Its caption identifies Momsen as the inventor; Washington D.C. naval yard as the location.
Hah, and there's this 1953 Navy training film which starting about 7:45 shows how the middle gadget above (the "S.E.A") is supposed to save you. (Hmm… )

Thanks Bill Forbes for identifying the "Momsen Lung", and thank you Ross for continuing the work and identifying the Davis Submerged Escape Apparatus and the Dräger Gegenlunge. We'll add this info the catalog record.

I think part of the reason I like this photo is the look on the 3 guys' faces. I also like that they kept on their shoes and socks.
Haha—yeah, they are looking somewhat less than enthused.

We recently found some old catalog cards for Harris & Ewing that had a caption for this photo. Harris & Ewing's caption for this photo is: 

"NO, NOT GAS MASKS. WASHINGTON, D.C. October 17--These mechanized looking gentlemen are not demonstrating a new kind of gas mask, but are demonstrating the different kinds of submarine escape apparatii as used by Germany, U.S. and England. From the left--Melvin Cottrell, Do’sun’s mate [should be bo’sun’s mate] 1st Class demonstrates the German, Luois Zampligione, gunners mate 1st class, the American, and Leslie Jones, besun’s mate [bo’sun’s mate] 1st class, the English. Although different designs, these masks are all operated under the same principle--oxygen tanks. They can also be used as gas masks whenever there is danger of chlorine gas inundating a submarine."

some biographical details in a New York Sun account of his death; "lieut.-Col. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ishii_Kikujirō "Viscount Ishii Kikujirō (石井 菊次郎?, April 24, 1866 – May 25, 1945), was a Japanese diplomat and cabinet minister in Meiji, Taishō and early Shōwa period Japan. He served as Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Empire of Japan between 1915 and 1916." "As special envoy to the United States from 1917–1918, he negotiated the Lansing–Ishii Agreement, which was intended to defuse tension between the two nations, but was limited in its effectiveness due to the reluctance of either government to make any concessions. Ishii stayed on in the United States as ambassador from 1918–1919."

Ludwig von Salm-Hoogstraeten (24 February 1885 – 23 July 1944), Austrian tennis player en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ludwig_von_Salm-Hoogstraeten (PS: this was his brother) In American newspapers he appears as "Count Otto Salm-Hoogstraeten", s. e.g. The sun., July 01, 1917, Section 2, Page 3, col. 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1917-07-01/ed-..., but it's apparently the same man.
see also and thepeerage.com/p9788.htm#i97878 which lists his birth and death differently than Wikipedia: " b. 25 August 1886, d. 1941"

The NYT, April 21, 1916 reported that Otto Salm-Hoogstraeten had an elder brother Ludwig, who was military aid to the governor of Vienna. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=980DE3DD113FE2... This conforms to the wikipedia entry of Ludwig, so the man on the photo is indeed Otto, not Ludwig.

A November, 1920 account of the tennis-playing Salm brothers from American Lawn Tennis magazine: "Count Otto Salm Goes Home Count Otto Salm well known in tournament play in the East during the half dozen years returned to his home in Vienna several months ago accompanied by Countess Salm who was an American girl. It is understood that he expects to remain in Vienna for some time perhaps permanently. Salm was one of three brothers prominent in lawn tennis. The eldest and the best player is Ludwig who remained in Europe during the war and was engaged in it on the Austrian side of course. The youngest brother Alexander came to New York with Otto about 1912 accompanied by Georges Aranyi a Hungarian who had been engaged in business in Paris. The three took part in a number of tournaments in this country, Otto being the most consistent participant in match play as well as the most successful. He won the Maine championship if memory serves before this country became involved in the war and he had some other good performances to his credit. His play was at times brilliant but nearly always erratic. Both Otto Salm and Aranyi became involved in the ban placed on enemy players by the USLTA and they did not compete in tournaments here after 1916." books.google.com/books?id=6GQ-AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA534&l...
Thanks, All, we'll add Otto's name to record.

Paul Alexander Wolf (1868-1954) A 1920 biographical sketch: "Paul Alexander Wolf commander of the Sixty sixth Infantry Brigade is a native of the state whose soldiers he led in France He was born in Kewanee Illinois December 23 1868 and was appointed to West Point from Princeton Illinois in 1886 Following his graduation General Wolf then a second lieutenant served with the Third Infantry in the winter of 1890 91 in the last important Indian campaign that against the Sioux in South Dakota He served in Cuba in the Spanish American War and in the Philippines from 1899 to 1902 being on the staff of General Frederick Funston during a part of the time He served in the Philippines again from 1903 to 1905 taking active part in the third Moro campaign on the staff of Major General Leonard Wood In 1913 and 1914 he was on the Mexican border and in April of the latter year he went to Vera Cruz Mexico where he served as chief of public works during the seven months of American occupation General Wolf was made a lieutenant colonel in 1916 and a colonel in the National Army in August 191 7 He commanded the two officers training camps at Plattsburg New York from May 1 to December 22 191 7 and commissioned 8,000 officers from these camps He was promoted to the rank of brigadier general in February 1918 and assigned to command the Sixty sixth Infantry Brigade of the Thirty third Division General Wolf led this brigade through the fighting in France and until its return to the United States in May 1919 He remained in France to serve as captain of the AEF rifle team which won first place in the inter allied competition at Le Mans in July 1919 General Wolf's services were recognized by the United States government by the award of the Distinguished Service Medal He received also the decorations of Officer of the Legion of Honor and the Croix de Guerre with Palm from the French and Companion of the Bath from the British " books.google.com/books?id=geALAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA173&l... www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=131763307

Defeated in the first round of the 1917 U.S. Championships: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B00E6DC103AE4... From the Jews in Sports site: "Rosenbaum, William The first known Jewish player to achieve an American ranking, William didn't play tennis full-time due to his prolific dental practice. Dr. Rosenbaum later became the chairman of the New York Oral Surgery Society, but remained close to the game by officiating at times. Birth and Death Dates: b 1888 - d. Sept. 16, 1951 Career Highlights: Rosenbaum was 63rd as the first American ranked Jew and had a career best ranking in class three of No. 31-No. 40 in 1914-1915. Even though he graduated from the New York University College of Dentistry, William managed to win the National indoor doubles championship twice and was runner-up in the National indoor singles championship in 1914. Later in his career, Rosenbaum won five National outdoor senior doubles crowns. "

The Russian Ambassador is probably Kurupensky www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/21133010018/ the British ambassador to Japan was Sir William Conyngham Greene (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conyngham_Greene)

The Russian ambassador to Japan in 1917 was Vasily Nikolaevich Krupensky (1868-1945) He was ambassador from 1916-1921. Krupensky is the modern transliteration and is more accurate to the original Russian Крупенский than Kurupensky, used by Bain. ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%83%D0%BF%D0%B5%D0%B... uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D1%80%D1%83%D0%BF%D0%B5%D0%B... Some contemporary sources also refer to him as Basil Krupenski or Krupensky.
